[[File:Флаг движения "Антимайдан".jpg|thumb|Antimaidan flag depicting Russian symbols of [[the Motherland Calls]] monument and [[ribbon of St. George]]]] [[File:Kyiv Ukraine 'Antimaidan' 14.12.2013 002.JPG|thumb|180px|Anti-Maidan in Kiev, 14 December 2013]]
The '''anti-Maidan''' ({{lang-ru|Антимайдан}}) refers to a number of demonstrations in [[Ukraine]] first directed against the [[Euromaidan]] and later the new Ukrainian government. The initial participants were in favor of supporting the cabinet of the [[second Azarov government]], [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]], and [[Russophilia|closer ties]] with [[Russia]]. After the [[2014 Ukrainian coup|overthrow of Yanukovych]], anti-Maidan became divided into various other groups, which partially overlapped. These ranged from people protesting against social ills, to supporters of a federalization of Ukraine, to [[pro-Russian]] [[separatists]] and [[nationalists]].<ref>https://blogs.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/2014/05/09/south-eastern-ukraine-extremism-and-the-anti-maidan/</ref>
==Protests of Anti-Maidan by date==
===November 2013 rallies=== A pro-[[Second Azarov Government|government]] counter protest reportedly gathered 10,000 people on 25 November (the reference does not contain any information about the pro-government protests).<ref>{{cite news|title=Huge demonstration in Kyiv in support of EU pact|url=http://www.euractiv.com/europes-east/huge-demonstration-kyiv-demands-news-531924|accessdate=26 November 2013|newspaper=EurActiv|date=25 November 2013}}</ref> The [[Party of Regions]] allegedly paid [[Ukrainian hryvnia|UAH]]₴100 to its supporters to participate in a three-hour rally, with supporters calling for "building Europe in Ukraine [...] but on terms and conditions favourable for Ukraine".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interpretermag.com/maidan-2-0-a-protest-with-reservations/|title=Maidan 2.0: A Protest With Reservations|publisher=The Interpreter|date=25 November 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> According to the ''[[Kyiv Post]]'', demonstrators held [[anti-EU]] and [[LGBT rights in Ukraine|homophobic]] banners (wrong reference).<ref name="UW291113R&opub">[http://www.kyivpost.com/guide/about-kyiv/musicians-liven-up-euromaidan-stage-332611.html Musicians liven up EuroMaidan stage], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 November 2013)</ref> On 29 November a 2-hour 3,000 people strong pro-government rally took place on [[European Square, Kiev|European Square]].<ref name=KPUEM2711>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/euromaidan-rallies-in-ukraine-live-updates-332341.html Live updates of the protests], [[Kyiv Post]] (27, 28 and 29 November 2013)</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.kyivpost.com/multimedia/photo/demonstrators-at-a-pro-government-rally-at-kyivs-european-square-332662.html|title=Demonstrators at pro-government rally at Kyiv's European Square|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=29 November 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> Party of Regions member of parliament Vladyslav Lukianov told the crowd: "I'm sure that our movement to Europe will never change. We support this choice. Let the land shatter from our steps. Together we will win".<ref name=KPUEM2711/><ref name="Seven News Ukraine 291113">[http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/20081107/ukraine-opposition-demands-leader-resign-after-eu-snub/ Ukraine opposition demands leader resign after EU snub], [[Seven News]] (30 November 2013)</ref> The ''Kyiv Post'' again reported incentives were given to attend and described attendants in appearance "to be homeless; still more look drunk. The crowd consists mostly of men".<ref name=KPUEM2711/> [[Euronews]] spoke of many being "bused in from the east of the country where pro-Russian sentiment is strong. They, too, carried national flags as well as those of the ruling Party of Regions".<ref name=ENBEU291113>[http://www.euronews.com/2013/11/29/ukraine-s-rejection-of-eu-deal-brings-rival-rallies-at-home/ Ukraine's rejection of EU deal brings rival rallies at home], [[Euronews]] (29 November 2013)</ref> Many in the crowd refused to talk to Euronews.<ref name="notalkieEuronews">[http://www.euronews.com/2013/11/29/ukraine-tension-in-kyiv-as-pro-and-anti-government-protesters-hold-rallies/ Ukraine: tension in Kyiv as pro and anti government protesters hold rallies], [[Euronews]] (29 November 2013)</ref>
On 30 November, several thousand protesters had been brought into [[Kharkiv]] on buses to stage a rally to support the government on [[Freedom Square, Kharkiv|Freedom Square]]. Some 170 buses were reported on the scene, and the number of attendees was according to organisers allegedly over 70,000;<ref name=kharkiv70k>{{cite news|url=http://interfax.com.ua/news/political/177921.html|script-title=ru:Митинг в поддержку действий президента по защите национальных интересов Украины прошел в Харькове|publisher=Interfax-Ukraine|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=4 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> news agencies reported the size of the crowd to be 40,000.<ref name=kharkiv40k>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В Харькове провели масштабный провластный митинг|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/rolling_news_russian/2013/11/131130_ru_n_kharkiv_meeting.shtml|newspaper=BBC|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=30 November 2013|language=ru}}</ref> The event lasted only 1 hour.<ref name=kharkiv40k/> Reports indicated attendees were paid [[Ukrainian hryvnia|UAH]]₴50 to attend,<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Швайка назвал харьковский Антимайдан фарсом|url=http://kharkov.comments.ua/news/2013/11/30/172710.html|newspaper=Kharkov Commentary|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=30 November 2013|language=ru}}</ref> and reports indicated that many were public sector workers who did not attend on their own accord.<ref name=kharkiv70k/> The rally was both pro-administration and pro-European Integration.<ref name=kharkiv70k/>
A rally in support of President Yanukovych held by the [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk Regional State Administration]] and the Party of Regions was to be held in Donetsk on 2 December, but was cancelled due to failure to organise enough people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://novosti.dn.ua/details/214090/|script-title=ru:Новости Донбасса :: В Донецке Партия Регионов отменила митинг в поддержку Януковича|publisher=Novosti.dn.ua|date=3 December 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>
On 3 December, 1,000 attended a rally in Kiev put on by the Party of Regions to support the president.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/25187987.html|script-title=uk:Партія регіонів оголосила про початок всеукраїнської акції на підтримку Януковича|publisher=Radio Svoboda|date=3 December 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref> The same day, it was reported by journalists of [[Espreso.tv]] that a Party of Regions organised rally in Kiev was paying [[Ukrainian hryvnia|UAH]]₴200 to participants via online job postings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zp.comments.ua/news/2013/12/03/163349.html|script-title=uk:"Титушкой" можно стать за 200 гривен|publisher=Zp.comments.ua|accessdate=4 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref>
On 4 December, 15,000 rallied in Donetsk in support of the president, many of whom were bussed in.<ref name=donetsk15k>{{cite web|url= http://gazeta.ua/ru/articles/life/_na-provlastnyj-miting-v-donecke-privezli-neskolko-desyatkov-avtobusov-neravnodus/529911 |title=На провластный митинг в Донецке привезли несколько десятков автобусов "неравнодушных"|publisher=Gazeta.ua|date=23 July 2013|accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref> The Party of Regions denied any allegations of forcing anyone to attend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://donetsk.comments.ua/news/2013/12/04/120554.html |title="Регионалы" утверждают, что шахтеры в Донецке будут митинговать за власть по своей воле|publisher=Donetsk.comments.ua|date=4 December 2013|accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref>
===December 2013 rallies in Mariinsky park=== [[File:Antimaidan. Mariinsky park in Kyiv. Orthodox Political Christians against «eurosodomy».JPG|thumb|right|Russian Orthodox ''Anti-Maidan'' protesters waving [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russian]] flags and orthodox banners]] A rally and tent camp action in support of President Viktor Yanukovych and at initiative of the [[Party of Regions]] began on 3 December in [[Mariinsky park]] located close by the [[Verkhovna Rada building]] (the parliament).<ref name="PoRtents51213">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/179397.html Police block part of govt quarter in central Kyiv], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (5 December 2013)</ref><ref name=PorCIU81213/> The Party of Regions's press service reported on Sunday 6 December that over 15,000 people were taking part in a pro-government rally there.<ref name=PorCIU81213/> According to city police, there were some 3,000 people in the park the day before.,<ref name=PorCIU81213>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/179986.html Several thousand Regions Party activists continue rally in support of Yanukovych], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2013)</ref> and the press estimated them at 2,000.<ref name="Segodnya on forced Dec 8 rally"/> Police heavily guarded this event from not only anti-government protesters,<ref name="BBC rally Dec 8">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-25290959|title=Ukraine's capital Kiev gripped by huge pro-EU demonstration|work=[[BBC News]]|date=8 December 2013| accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> but also from any journalists and on-lookers.
According to [[Segodnya]], people attending the pro-government Marinsky Park event were hired or obliged to attend, and forced to stay for a pre-determined time. In one incident on 8 December, protesters were held at the rally against their will by armed security.<ref name="Segodnya on forced Dec 8 rally">{{cite news|url= http://www.segodnya.ua/ukraine/s-mitinga-partii-regionov-sbegayut-lyudi-ih-lovyat-pravoohraniteli-480943.html|script-title=ru:С митинга Партии регионов сбегают госслужащие, их ловят люди в черном|work=[[Segodnya]]|date=8 December 2013|accessdate=9 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Not seen in any other news outlets AFAIK|date=December 2013}}
Speaking on condition of anonymity to the ''Kyiv Post'', one demonstrator said that participants of the rally are paid [[Ukrainian hryvnia|UAH]]₴300 or more in order to earn money without going to work. She also recalled cases when they were not let outside the rally for the whole day, while inside the camp there was a build up of garbage and dirty toilets on the grounds.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.kyivpost.com/multimedia/photo/regions-rally-333539.html|title=Pro-government protesters: 'We will stay here until EuroMaidan leaves'|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=12 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref> [[Mark MacKinnon]], senior international correspondent for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', attempted to interview a demonstrator at the ongoing Anti-Maidan, but although was refused the demonstrator indicated to him that she actually supported the Euromaidan protests.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.twitter.com/markmackinnon/status/411180793721937920|title=Twitter / markmackinnon: First woman I spoke to at|publisher=Twitter.com|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref>
In parliament on 13 December Svoboda leader Oleh Tyahnybok said people on the government payroll in medical, education and other sectors (the so-called "byudzhetnye" sectors) were being bullied into coming to a planned pro-government rally that weekend; Speaker of parliament and Party of Regions member [[Volodymyr Vasylyovych Rybak|Volodymyr Rybak]] responded, saying that it is wrong to pressure people and it has to stop.<ref name=KPLIVEd13/>
On 23 December, the pro-government rally ended.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.kyivpost.com/multimedia/photo/pro-government-and-euromaidan-protesters-on-dec-23-334156.html|author=Anastasia Vlasova|authorlink=Anastasia Vlasova (journalist)|title=Pro-government protest closes as EuroMaidan goes on|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=23 December 2013|accessdate=23 December 2013}}</ref>
===14–15 December 2013 rally in European Square=== [[File:Antimaidan.JPG|thumb|left|upright=0.8|[[Militsiya|Police]] guard the entrance to the 'Anti-Maidan' demonstration site on [[European Square (Kiev)|European Square]], Kiev, on the morning of 14 December.]] [[File:Nmlkhreshchatyk.JPG|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The 'corridor' on [[Khreshchatyk]] between the Euromaidan and 'Anti-Maidan' demonstrations, looking towards Maidan Nezalezhnosti, 8:00 am, 14 December.]] On 14 December the Party of Regions announced that they intended to hold a rally on [[European Square (Kiev)|European Square]] under the banner "Let's Save Ukraine".<ref name=KPLIVEd13>{{cite news|title=EuroMaidan rallies in Ukraine|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/euromaidan-rallies-in-ukraine-live-updates-333360.html|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=13 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=dec14antimaidan>{{cite web|title=ANNOUNCEMENT rally "to preserve Ukraine" (АНОНС митинга "СОХРАНИМ УКРАИНУ") |url=http://partyofregions.ua/news/event/52ab02e7c4ca421477000108 |publisher=Party of Regions |accessdate=13 December 2013 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213203353/http://partyofregions.ua/news/event/52ab02e7c4ca421477000108 |archivedate=13 December 2013 }}</ref> The move to create a second rally in the city by officials was condemned by former president [[Leonid Kravchuk]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52ab7dcfa37e4/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213223359/http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52ab7dcfa37e4/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 December 2013 |script-title=uk:Кравчук засудив спроби зібрати другий Майдан |agency=[[The Insider (newspaper)|The Insider]] |date=13 December 2013 |accessdate=15 December 2013 |language=uk }}</ref> According to party officials, 20,000 were expected to come from [[Donetsk]] and 10,000 from [[Dnipropetrovsk Oblast]].<ref name=KPLIVEd13/> Many others were expected to arrive from the [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]], [[Odessa Oblast]], and a number of other regions.<ref name=warning15/> In the lead up to the rally, it was reported on 12 December that "thousands" of residents from [[Dnipropetrovsk]] (mostly government employees, students of technical schools, and athletes) were traveling to Kiev to join in the pro-government rallies. Those interviewed said they were doing so reluctantly, and only for two days, at a rate of [[Ukrainian hryvnia|UAH]]₴400–500 a day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52aa28010d977/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213000801/http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52aa28010d977/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 December 2013 |script-title=uk:З Дніпропетровська на київський "антимайдан" везуть 1 тис. бюджетників |agency=[[The Insider (newspaper)|The Insider]] |date=12 December 2013 |accessdate=15 December 2013 |language=uk }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://comments.ua/politics/442050-dnepropetrovska-kiev-viehala.html|script-title=ru:Из Днепропетровска в Киев выехала колонна "спортсменов" и бюджетников (ВИДЕО)|publisher=Comments.ua|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> It was also reported that state employees were coerced to join the group under threat of dismissal.<ref name="comments1">{{cite news| work = Dnepr|url=http://dnepr.comments.ua/news/2013/12/12/175543.html|script-title=ru:Днепропетровских бюджетников заставляют ехать в Киев на 'Антимайдан'|trans-title=Dnepropetrovsk state employees are forced to go to Kiev to 'Antimaydan'|publisher=Comments|place=UA|date=12 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> On the day of the rally, UDAR MP Roman Chereha accused officials of bringing in children from shelters, promising them food and shelter.<ref name=insiderlivedec14/> On 13 December, the Donetsk regional organisation of The Party of Regions said that people wishing to go to Kiev would be provided food rations and would be transported on a specially commissioned train, paid for by the party.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Из Донецка в Киев отправляется спецпоезд со сторонниками Президента|url=http://www.unian.net/news/611838-iz-donetska-v-kiev-otpravlyaetsya-spetspoezd-so-storonnikami-prezidenta.html|agency=UNIAN|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> In Odessa, several trains carrying roughly 3,000 departed the city carrying students and teachers to participate in the pro-government rally; students, some from the Odessa Law Academy, admitted they would receive school credit for attending; others would receive financial compensation.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Из Одессы выехали три поезда со студентами для участия в провластных митингах|url= http://www.unian.net/news/611932-iz-odessyi-vyiehali-tri-poezda-so-studentami-dlya-uchastiya-v-provlastnyih-mitingah.html|newspaper=UNIAN|date=13 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> It was similarly reported in [[Luhansk]] that over 1,000 had departed via rail, and those attending were largely coal miners from the region. Luhansk mayor Sergei Kravchenko in an address stated that over 1,500 residents would support the government at the rally.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Луганск отправил на "антимайдан" в Киев спецпоезд из 19 вагонов|url=http://www.unian.net/news/611922-lugansk-otpravil-na-antimaydan-v-kiev-spetspoezd-iz-19-vagonov.html|newspaper=UNIAN|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> Meanwhile, in [[Zaporizhia]], it was reported that a train packed with 1,600 "athletic men and workers of state enterprises and companies" was departing to Kiev. Conductors said it was a private, rented train with tickets not available to the public.<ref name=KPLIVEd13/> In a list released by journalist Tatiana Honchenko, a total of 27 trains, each with on average 20 cars had been rented by the Party of Regions for the weekend event to transport supporters from across Ukraine to Kiev.<ref>{{cite news|script-title=uk:В Інтернеті оприлюднили список поїздів з "тітушками" та бюджетниками|url= http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/12/13/7006806/|newspaper=Ukrayinska Pravda|date= 13 December 2013|accessdate=14 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref>
Opposition leaders [[Arseniy Yatseniuk]] and [[Ihor Miroshnychenko]] issued a warning, citing inside information, that authorities were planning to use the large pro-government rally in order to start a civil conflict and justify issuing a [[state of emergency]], which would require the use of Berkut riot police and military to clear European Square and Maidan.<ref name=warning15>{{cite news|title= Яценюк: Власть готовит широкомасштабные провокации на выходные|url=http://zn.ua/POLITICS/yacenyuk-vlast-gotovit-shirokomasshtabnye-provokacii-na-vyhodnye-134934_.html|newspaper=[[Zerkalo Nedeli]]|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=14 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=d15op>{{cite news|title=Opposition warns of Yanukovych attempts to instigate violence at Dec. 15 rally|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/opposition-warns-of-yanukoyvch-attempts-to-instigate-violence-at-dec-15-rally-333637.html|author=Mark Rachkevych|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=14 December 2013}}</ref> Yatsenyuk specifically warned against the use of hired thugs ([[titushky]]) who will infiltrate and start to wreak havoc in the pro-European encampment cloaked in either European Union or national colours.<ref name=warning15/> Opposition leader Yuriy Lutsenko, however, called for calm and assured that the pro-government rally will be attended by peaceful, state-paid employees and students.<ref name=warning15/> [[Oleksandr Yefremov]], head of the Party of Regions parliamentary faction reiterated: "This will be an exclusively peaceful demonstration, our people are always easy to get along with ... we will also rely on the police to create a safe buffer between the two rallies".<ref name=warning15/> However, a statement by Party of Regions MP Vadym Kolesnichenko acknowledged the creation of vigilante groups being formed in the south-east of Ukraine and across [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]] to "protect public order and the Constitution", and that one such group in [[Sevastopol]] already had already amassed 800 recruits; adding that they would be involved in the events of the weekend.<ref name=kolesvigil>{{cite news|script-title=ru:"Регионал" Колесниченко: В Крыму и юго-востоке Украины создадут отряды самообороны для защиты госстроя|url=http://interfax.com.ua/news/political/181478.html|newspaper=Interfax-Ukraine|date=12 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> In an interview by [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] with an attendee on the day of the event, the subject (who taught boxing) revealed that he and a group of others were offered [[Ukrainian hryvnia|UAH]]₴1,000 by organisers to instigate a fight with protesters on Maidan.<ref>{{cite web|author=Наталія Седлецька|url= http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/25200979.html|script-title=uk:Спортсмени відмовились вчиняти бійки на Євромайдані за 1000 гривень – сповідь "антимайданівця" |publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref>
The Interior Ministry's press service told the ''Kyiv Post'' on 13 December that the pro-government rally received permission to have up to 200,000 in attendance.<ref name=KPLIVEd13/> According to [[Zerkalo Nedeli]], one of the nation's most influential newspapers, the [[National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine]] and government ordered the [[Ministry of Defence (Ukraine)|Ministry of Defense]] to aid in the provision of security, logistics, deployment of field kitchens, and transportation of 200,000 civilians to hold a pro-government rally in Kiev on the weekend of 14–15 December.<ref name=zn200k>{{cite news|title=Власть с помощью армии готовит на выходные альтернативный 200-тысячный митинг 191|url= http://zn.ua/POLITICS/vlast-s-pomoschyu-armii-gotovit-na-vyhodnye-alternativnyy-200-tysyachnyy-miting-134834_.html|newspaper=ZN|date=11 December 2013|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref> The Ministry of Internal Affairs is said to have been requested to aid in the security for those coming to Kiev from other regions of the country.<ref name=zn200k/> The report was covered in the media by The Insider,<ref>{{cite news|script-title=uk:Військовим доручили годувати мітинг на підтримку Януковича,-ЗМІ |url=http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52a899567a3bf/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213203545/http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52a899567a3bf/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 December 2013 |accessdate=11 December 2013 |newspaper=The Insider |language=uk }}</ref> [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]],<ref name=unian200k>{{cite news|script-title=ru:СМИ: Власть готовит на выходные альтернативный 200-тысячный митинг|url=http://www.unian.net/news/611397-smi-vlast-gotovit-na-vyihodnyie-alternativnyiy-200-tyisyachnyiy-miting.html|newspaper=UNIAN|date=11 December 2013|accessdate=12 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> and [[Ukrayinska Pravda]].<ref name=pravda200k>{{cite news|script-title=uk:Влада за допомогою армії готує 200-тисячний мітинг-джерело|url=http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/12/11/7006376/ |newspaper=Ukrainian Pravda|date=11 December 2013|accessdate=12 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref> The Minister of Defense later denied these rumors, citing Article 17 and Article 37 of the [[Ukrainian Constitution]], which prohibits the participation of the Ukrainian Armed Forces in domestic political fights.<ref>{{cite news|last=Interfax-Ukraine|title=Defense Minister: Ukrainian Armed Forces not involved in political rallies in Kyiv|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/defense-minister-ukrainian-armed-forces-not-involved-in-political-rallies-in-kyiv-333576.html|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=14 December 2013}}</ref> Despite this, on 13 December tents were seen being set up on property owned by the Ministry of Defense,<ref>{{cite news|script-title=uk:Опозиція чекає від влади серйозну провокацію на вихідних (ФОТО)|url=http://ua.comments.ua/politics/217019-opozitsiya-chekaie-vid-vladi-seryoznu.html|newspaper=Commentary|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=14 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref> and in a separate report by Zerkalo Nedeli it was revealed that the Ministry of Defense had been conducting training exercises over the previous two days, including taking inventory of equipment (ex. field kitchens, vehicles) for support of the pro-governmental protests. Resources were also transferred to ''Ukpromakord'', the food supplier of the Ukrainian Armed Forces.<ref>{{cite news|title=Міністр оборони втягує армію у політичний конфлікт|url=http://dt.ua/POLITICS/ministr-oboroni-vtyaguye-armiyu-u-politichniy-konflikt-133841_.html|newspaper=ZN|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref> Further, on the day of the event witnesses reported and photographed 40 military field kitchens serving pro-government supporters in Mariinsky Park.<ref name=insiderlivedec14>{{cite news|title=December 14 Live |url=http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/maidan-14-grudnya-live/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214195925/http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/maidan-14-grudnya-live/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 December 2013 |newspaper=The Insider |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=15 December 2013 |language=uk }}</ref>
Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]] spoke at the rally and told attendants that Ukraine did not decline its goal of integrating to the EU: "We're allegedly betray Ukraine and sign [the agreement on joining] the Customs Union of Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Russia. I strongly deny these speculations".<ref name="AsNCUIU141213">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/181851.html Azarov says rumors on Ukraine's joining Customs Union profiteering], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (14 December 2013)</ref> He referred to statements that Ukrainian authorities where planning to join this [[Customs Union]] as "[[Profiteering (business)|profiteering]]".<ref name="AsNCUIU141213"/> Azarov also urged, "Don't divide Ukraine, don't build barricades".<ref>[http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/ukraine-suspends-mayor-security-official-over-protest-crackdown_896844.html Ukraine suspends mayor, security official over protest crackdown], [[Zee News]] (14 December 2013)</ref> Azarov also said the EU had insisted on 'unacceptable conditions' sign the AA, including the introduction of gay marriage and laws protecting sexual minorities. "The opposition leaders are telling fables when they say that we only have to sign the [association] agreement [with the EU] to start traveling to Europe visa-free the next day. Nothing of the sort. We have yet to comply with a whole set of preconditions: we have to legalise same-sex marriages, we have to adopt legislation on equality of sexual minorities, and so on. Is our society ready for this?" Azarov said.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://en.ria.ru/world/20131214/185553850/Kiev-Prepares-Roadmap-for-Joining-Russian-Led-Customs-Union--Report.html|title=Ukraine on Brink of Economic Deal With Russia – Premier|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref> Azarov has subsequently decamped to Vienna, where he maintains a palatial home.
At the event, Party of Regions MP Hryhoriy Smitiukh called attendees to appeal to Russian president Vladimir Putin to lower the price of gas in Ukraine, and engaged the crowd in a chant of "Putin! Putin!"<ref name=insiderlivedec14/>
Organisers claimed over 100,000 attended;<ref>{{cite web|url= http://crimea.comments.ua/news/2013/12/14/134543.html|script-title=ru:"Регионалы" насчитали на своем митинге 100 тысяч|publisher=Crimea.comments.ua|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> police estimated 60,000 attended, which was also estimated to be the maximum capacity of the square;<ref name=antimaidan200not>{{cite news|script-title=uk:"Регіонали" зібрали на свій мітинг 200 тисяч там, де вміщується лише 20|url= http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/12/14/7006871/|newspaper=Ukrainian Pravda|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref> eyewitnesses placed the attendance as low as 20,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=Victor Ognienko |url=http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52aca84f175b7 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214222846/http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52aca84f175b7/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 December 2013 |script-title=ru:Регионы не смогли превозмочь Майдан массой |agency=[[The Insider (newspaper)|The Insider]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=15 December 2013 |language=ru }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/euromaidan-rallies-in-ukraine-saturday-dec14-live-updates-333634.html|title=EuroMaidan rallies in Ukraine – Dec. 14 |newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref> At 6:00 p.m. Party of Regions head Oleksandr Efremov announced the end of the meeting, a day earlier than planned.<ref name=kplived14>{{cite news|title=Dec 14 Live|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/euromaidan-rallies-in-ukraine-saturday-dec14-live-updates-333634.html|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref> By the end of the rally, only 3,000 remained,<ref name=insiderlivedec14/> and by the evening European Square was deserted.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.twitter.com/berdynskykh_k/status/411919103876931585/photo/1|title=Twitter / berdynskykh_k: Антимайдан|publisher=Twitter.com|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref>
The rally on 15 December ran from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., and there were various reports that attendees were not paid in full for their time. "People came to express their will. We paid them Hr 300 per day. I did not promise any money to them, I am here with my voters," said Artur Martovytskiy, a lawmaker from the Party of Regions.<ref name=paidpor>{{cite news|url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/life/_kozhnogo-privezenogo-na-stolichnij-antimajdan-oshukali-na-500-grn/531990|script-title=ru:Кожного привезеного на столичний "антимайдан" ошукали на 500 грн|newspaper=Gazeta|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>
===January 2014 rally in Mariinsky park=== Another rally by supporters of the Party of Regions began on 13 January 2014 and continued until the adoption of the state budget for 2014 on 17 January.<ref name=AMIU13114/><ref name=GSacIU21114>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/186773.html Government supporters again rallying near parliament, this time against 'coup'], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 January 2014)</ref> According to the organisers people are attending the rally because they want "stability in the country" and believe that it is unacceptable to hinder the adoption of the state budget.<ref name=AMIU13114/> Protesters are planning to spend the night in the tent city in [[Mariinsky park]].<ref name=AMIU13114/> According to the organisers participants in the rally were collecting signatures that will be sent to the [[Kiev city council]] with the request to free the center of Kiev of demonstrators, including [[Khreshchatyk]] and [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]].<ref name=AMIU13114/> The organisers stated that the protesters were in favour of a peaceful solution to this issue and were against the violent dispersal of the pro-European rally.<ref name=AMIU13114/> [[Interfax-Ukraine]] reported on 13 January that about ten tents had been set up in the park and metal shields had been installed perpendicular to [[Hrushevskoho Street]], with law enforcement officers standing behind them.<ref name=AMIU13114>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/185515.html Party of Regions supporters begin rally near parliament, planning to stay until adoption of budget], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (13 January 2014)</ref>
Prime Minister Azarov criticised Euromaidan coverage in western media, and lack of attention to the 'anti-Maidan', "The Western media are paying attention to one square and do not pay for another," and said that the ''anti-maidan'' represents all of Ukraine, whereas Euromaidan as a whole only represents Lviv, Ternopil, and Ivano-Frankivsk. He then stated that the majority of Ukraine supports the president, the government, and no longer has interest in European integration.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/01/21/7010523/|script-title=uk:Азаров: на Антимайдані люди з усіх областей, а на Майдані – з декількох|newspaper=Ukrayinska Pravda|date=21 January 2014|accessdate=24 January 2014|language=uk}}</ref>
Another rally by supporters of the Party of Regions (planned to bring up to 10,000 attendees) in Mariinsky park began on 21 January 2014 against an alleged attempted "coup" by the Euromaidan protesters.<ref name=GSacIU21114/> It is planned to continue until the end of the [[2014 Hrushevskoho Street riots]].<ref name=GSacIU21114/>
==Other antimaidans== The [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] planned to gather 2,000 supporters to a 24 November 2013 rally against signing agreements with the European Union.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/numerous-parties-associations-plan-rallies-in-kyiv-on-sunday-332350.html|title= Numerous parties, associations plan rallies in Kyiv on Sunday|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=23 November 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> Communists who attended set up tents near the [[List of Communist monuments in Ukraine#Standing|statue of Lenin in Kyiv]], intending to protect it from vandalism.<ref>{{cite news|author=Daryna Shevchenko |url= http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/news-blog-dozens-police-officers-guard-lenin-monumnet-in-kyiv-on-nov-24-332408.html|title= Heavy police protection, just for Vladimir Lenin statue|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=25 November 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>
On 25 November in [[Sevastopol]] the [[Russian Bloc (party)|Russian Bloc]] and the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] organised an "antimaidan".<ref name=antimaidan>{{cite news | url = https://newdaynews.ru/sevas/472345.html | title = In Sevastopol the Russian Bloc and the Communist Party of Ukraine are gathering the antimaidan (В Севастополе "Русский блок" и КПУ собирают анти-майдан)| newspaper=NewDayNews.Ru|date=25 November 2013|accessdate=25 November 2013|language=ru}}</ref> The meeting was conducted in support of joining the [[Customs Union of Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Russia]].<ref name=antimaidan/> Previous rallies by the Russian Bloc in the weeks prior included EU flag burning and anti-government, and [[anti-Ukrainian]] rhetoric,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newdaynews.ru/sevas/470210.html|script-title=ru:"Свобода": Лозунги на маршах "Русского блока" были "откровенно антиукраинскими и антигосударственными"|publisher=NewDayNews.Ru|date=13 November 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|These rallies were described by [[Batkivshchyna]] MP [[Volodymyr Yavorivsky]] as "raving madness".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newdaynews.ru/sevas/469472.html|script-title=ru:"Батькивщина": Акции "Русского блока"|publisher=NewDayNews.Ru|date=8 November 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>|group=nb}} On 26 November, another antimaidan protest was organised in [[Donetsk]], attracting only 30 student protesters. Organisers stated that the European Union had ruined the economies of new members, and that joining would bring corruption and gay marriage.<ref name=donetskantimaidan>{{cite web|url= http://gazeta.ua/ru/articles/politics/_evropa-grozit-ukraine-razvratom-russkij-blok-provel-v-donecke-antimajdan/528245|script-title=ru:Европа грозит Украине развратом – "Русский блок" провел в Донецке "антимайдан"|newspaper=Gazeta|date=26 November 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> The protest was counter to the pro-EU EuroMaidan protest 200 meters away, which attracted no more than 50 protesters. The next day, a small antimaidan rally was held by the Russian Bloc and Communists in [[Mykolaiv]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://nikvesti.com/news/politics/47418|script-title=ru:На митинг рядом с Евромайданом в Николаеве вышли коммунисты и Русский блок|publisher=Nikvesti.com|date=27 November 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> At a 25 November rally in [[Luhansk]], protesters were met with resistance from a group of [[Don Cossacks]], who were against EU membership and referred to pro-EU protesters as fascists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politika.lg.ua/2013/11/lugansk-evrointegracionnyj-kazaki-gei-i-rpl/|script-title=ru:Луганск евроинтеграционный: казаки, геи и РПЛ|newspaper=Politika.lg.ua|date=25 November 2013|accessdate=8 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>
A 1 December Communist rally in Donetsk gathered about 200 mostly elderly supporters who chanted: "The union of Ukraine, Russia and Belarus is inevitable".<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-25198943 Donetsk view: Ukraine 'other half' resents Kiev protests], [[BBC News]] (3 December 2013)</ref> The following day, [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] MP Antonina Khromova made statements at the Donetsk regional council, approving the use of force to remove protesters in Kiev, which was met with applause. She continued by saying that Ukraine does not need ''European values'', namely, "same-sex marriage" and "African panhandlers".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://odessa.comments.ua/news/2013/12/02/164348.html|script-title=ru:В Донецке аплодировали "Беркуту" за столичный Евромайдан|publisher=Odessa.comments.ua|date=2 December 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref>
The [[Sevastopol]] city council, on the initiative of the Russian Bloc, opted to appeal to the President and the Government of Ukraine to reorient foreign policy towards Russia and its Customs Union.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://newdaynews.ru/sevas/473681.html |script-title=ru:Горсовет Севастополя по инициативе "Русского блока" потребовал от Януковича вступать в Таможенный союз / 02.12.13 / Севастополь|publisher=NewDayNews.Ru|date=30 May 2005|accessdate=4 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> The Russian Bloc has also demanded the resignation of Minister of Education Dmytro Tabachnyk, for not preventing students from taking part in the Euromaidan protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newdaynews.ru/sevas/473780.html|script-title=ru:"Русский блок" требует отставки министра образования Украины / 03.12.13 / Севастополь|publisher=NewDayNews.Ru|date=3 December 2013|accessdate=4 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> On 8 December, the "Russian Community of Sevastopol" organisation held a rally in support of Berkut anti-riot troops who made headlines for assaulting students and journalists in Kiev the week prior. Leader of the group, Tatiana Ermakova, expressed outrage at the fact that, according to her, protesters provoked and attacked Berkut troops. "No country in the world would allow such lawlessness which, for the 17th day occurs on the Maidan," she said.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.unian.net/news/610185-russkaya-obschina-sevastopolya-provela-aktsiyu-v-podderjku-berkuta.html|script-title=ru:"Русская община Севастополя" провела акцию в поддержку "Беркута": Новости УНИАН|newspaper=UNIAN|date=8 December 2013|accessdate=8 December 2013|language=ru}}</ref> The official statement from Russian Community specifically thanked the anti-riot troops for 'protecting us from the fascists', and called the Euromaidan demonstrators "[[Nazis]]" and "[[Banderite]]s".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://novoross.info/general/21706-chleny-obschestvennogo-soveta-i-simferopolcy-proveli-akciyu-v-podderzhku-berkuta-foto.html|title=Члены Общественного совета и симферопольцы провели акцию в поддержку "Беркута" (ФОТО) Новоросс.info – Информационный портал|publisher=Novoross.info|date=12 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref>
On 14 December the leaders of the Russian Bloc and [[Russian Unity]] met with the Consul General of Russia in Crimea, Vyacheslav Svitlychny, and declared the preparation of an ''antimaidan'' to demand the secession of [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]] from Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.theinsider.com.ua/politics/52ac634912f5c/ |script-title=uk:У Криму готується сепаратистський Євромайдан?|publisher=[[The Insider (newspaper)|The Insider]]|date=14 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013|language=uk}}</ref>
On 25 January, a pro-government antimaidan was held in [[Mykolayiv]], with attendees largely described as mostly young men, athletic, and appearing to be ''titushky''. The crowd of 400 spoke out against fascism and held signs promoting the unity of [[All-Russian nation|Ukraine, Belarus, and Russia]].<ref>{{cite news|url = http://nikvesti.com/news/politics/49093 |script-title=ru:Участники провластного митинга в Николаеве ожидают штурм ОГА со стороны футбольных фанатов и майдановцев|date=25 January 2013|accessdate=25 January 2013|language=ru}}</ref>
On 26 January, a rally took place against the Maidan movement in Simferopol, with 200 attending. Protesters accused journalists of killing people in Kiev.<ref>{{youtube|WgMwhBih498|В Криму думають, що журналісти когось вбивають / #Євромайдан}}</ref> 1,000 gathered in Donetsk, supported by local Regions supporters, communists, and [[neo-cossack]]s; clashes caused some injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://novosti.dn.ua/details/216964/|script-title=ru:В Донецке митинг в поддержку власти: мужчине разбили голову|date=26 January 2014|accessdate=26 January 2014|language=ru}}</ref>
On 1 February in Dnipropetrovsk, Communists held a rally in support of merging Ukraine with Russia and Belarus, and called for the imposition of curfews, the closing of banks, and the expulsion of foreigners.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zh7K4M9XZEI |title=YouTube |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=3 March 2014}}</ref>{{better source|date=March 2014}} In January 2015, an Anti-Maidan movement in Russia said it was ready to use violence to stop anti-government and pro-democracy protesters.<ref name=GN150115>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/15/group-anti-maidan-defend-russia-pro-democracy-protesters |title= Patriotic group formed to defend Russia against pro-democracy protesters |first= Shaun |last= Walker |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 15 January 2015 }}</ref>
==Criticism== Several news outlets have investigated the claims to confirm that by and large, attendees at pro-government rallies did so for financial compensation and not for political reasons, and were not an organic response to the [[Euromaidan]]. "People stand at Euromaidan protesting against the violation of human rights in the state, and they are ready to make sacrifices," said Oleksiy Haran, a political scientist at [[National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy|Kyiv Mohyla Academy]] in Kiev. "People at Antimaidan stand for money only. The government uses these hirelings to provoke resistance. They won't be sacrificing anything."<ref>{{cite news|last=Rudenko|first=Olga|title=Protesters: Ukraine paying for pro-government rallies|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/02/16/ukraine-government-protests/5435315/|newspaper=USA Today|date=16 February 2014}}</ref> However, 42 Antimaidan activists lost their lives in the [[2014 Odessa massacre|2014 Odessa fire]].
==Successors of the Anti-Maidan== * Ukrainskiy Front, the main successor of Anti-Maidan that replaced the movement and united all its branches ** Odesskaya Druzhina, an Odessa city branch ** Oplot, a Kharkiv city branch ** Oplot Donbassa (later - Russkaya Pravoslavnaya Armiya), a Donetsk city branch ** Armiya Yuga-Vostoka, a Luhansk city branch

{{More citations needed|date=July 2009}} {{Operation Condor}} The '''Argentine Anticommunist Alliance''' ({{lang-es|Alianza Anticomunista Argentina|links=no}}, usually known as '''Triple A''' or '''AAA''') was a [[far-right]] [[death squad]] founded in [[Argentina]] in 1973 and particularly active under [[Isabel Perón]]'s rule (1974–1976). Initially associated with the [[Peronist]] [[far-right politics|right]], the organisation opposed the Peronist [[far-left politics|left]] and other leftist organizations.<!--{{citation needed span|text=Many of its members later became linked to the [[National Reorganization Process|military junta]] led by [[Jorge Rafael Videla]] (1976–1983) and played a prominent role in the "[[Dirty War]]". |date=August 2012}}--> The AAA acted against a wide range of government opponents, not just [[Communism|communists]].
The Triple A allegedly was secretly led by [[José López Rega]], Minister of Social Welfare and personal secretary of [[Juan Perón]]. [[Rodolfo Almirón]], arrested in Spain in 2006, was alleged to be his chief operating officer of the group, and was officially head of López Rega's and Isabel Perón's personal security. He was extradited from Spain in 2006 and prosecuted; he died in jail in June 2009. [[SIDE]] agent [[Anibal Gordon]] was another important member of the Triple A, although he always denied it. He was tried in Argentina in 1985 after the restoration of democracy and convicted in October 1986. Gordon died in prison of [[lung cancer]] the next year.<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/1999/10/14/e-05402d.htm "Quién fue Aníbal Gordon?" (Who was Anibal Gordon), ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]],'' 14 October {{es icon}}]</ref>
In 2006, Argentine Judge [[Norberto Oyarbide]] ruled the Triple A had committed "[[crimes against humanity]]," which meant their crimes were exempt from statutes of limitations. Suspects can be prosecuted for actions committed in the 1970s and early 1980s.
==Creation== The ''Triple A'' was believed to have been organized in 1973 by José López Rega and [[Alberto Villar]], deputy chief of the [[Argentine federal police]], during the brief interim presidency of [[Raúl Lastiri]] in 1973. Reportedly, the movement was conceived at a high-level [[Peronist]] meeting on October 1, 1973, attended by President [[Raúl Lastiri]], Interior Minister [[Benito Llambí]], Social Welfare Minister [[José López Rega]], general secretary of the Presidency [[José Humberto Martiarena]] and various provincial governors.<ref>Manuel Justo Gaggero, [http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-80601-2007-02-19.html “El general en su laberinto”], ''[[Pagina/12]]'', 19 February 2007</ref> The group has been defined by legal rulings as part of state terrorism, operating under the governments of Lastiri, Perón and Isabel Perón through López Rega resignation and exile in July 1975. Villar and his wife were assassinated in 1974 with a bomb that was planted on his [[cabin cruiser]] in [[Tigre, Buenos Aires|Tigre]] by members of the ''[[Montoneros]]'', a militant, leftist group.
López Rega, a devotee of [[occultism]] and self-styled [[divination|divinator]], became a powerful force in the Peronist movement. He exerted great influence over [[Juan Perón|Perón]], who was elected to the presidency and took office in 1973, and his wife Isabel Martínez de Perón, elected as vice-president, who succeeded to the presidency upon Perón's sudden death on 1 July 1974. To support the paramilitary group, López Rega drew on funds from the Ministry of Social Welfare, which he controlled.<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2006/12/20/espana/1166608365.html "Un juez argentino ordena capturar al ex jefe de la 'Triple A', que vive en Valencia" (An Argentine judge ordered the capture of the ex-chief of 'Triple A', who lives in Valencia], ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'', December 20, 2006 {{es icon}}</ref> Some of the members of the Triple A had earlier taken part in the Peronist [[1973 Ezeiza massacre]]. On the day Perón returned from exile, snipers shot and killed numerous (13 at least killed) left-wing Peronists at the mass gathering to welcome his return, leading to the definitive separation between left and right-wing Peronists.
The Spanish Judge [[Baltazar Garzón]]'s investigations, directed at human rights abuses internationally, revealed that [[Italy|Italian]] [[neofascist]] [[Stefano Delle Chiaie]] had also worked with the Triple A, and was present at Ezeiza. Delle Chiaie also worked with the [[Chile]]an [[Dirección de Inteligencia Nacional|DINA]] in Chile, and for [[Hugo Banzer]], a [[Bolivia]]n [[dictator]].<ref name="Nizkor">{{Cite news| title=Las Relaciones secretas entre Pinochet, Franco y la P2 - Conspiración para matar (The Secret Relations between Pinochet, Franco and the P2 - Conspiracy for death) | publisher=[[Equipo Nizkor]] | date=1999-02-04|url=http://www.derechos.org/sorin/doc/p2.html|language=es}}</ref>
According to a 1983 ''[[New York Times]]'' article, the group was founded when there were an increasing number of guerrilla attacks by [[left-wing politics|left-wing militant]] groups,<ref>{{Cite news| title = "Ex-Argentine Security Chief Seized" |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world/ex-argentine-security-chief-seized.html| work=The New York Times| date = 1983-11-16}}</ref> which were met by harsh [[Political repression|repression]] of [[political dissident]]s on the part of the [[Military of Argentina|military]], [[paramilitary]] and [[police force]]s. This environment of social unrest was the justification used by the subsequent military junta for its [[Dirty War]] against political opponents. But testimony at the 1985 [[Trial of the Juntas|Juicio a las Juntas]] trial established that by 1976, both the [[People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)|ERP]] and the [[Montoneros]] had been dismantled, and the political dissidents had never posed a real threat to the government.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
==Victims== The group first came to national attention on 21 November 1973 in its attempt to murder Argentine [[Argentine Senate|Senator]] [[Hipólito Solari Yrigoyen]] by a [[car bomb]]. The AAA went on to kill 1,122 people, according to an appendix to the 1983 [[CONADEP]] report,<ref name="IPS">{{Cite news| title = Rights: Argentina Renews Hunt for 'Triple A' Death Squad | publisher = IPS | date = 2007-02-23}}</ref> including suspected Montoneros and [[People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)|ERP]] leftist [[guerrilla warfare|guerrillas]] and their sympathizers, but the group expanded its targets to other political opponents, including [[judge]]s, police chiefs, and [[social activist]]s. In total, it is suspected of having killed more than 1500 people.<ref name="Pulsar">[http://www.agenciapulsar.org/nota.php?id=9290 "Justicia argentina condenó delitos de la Triple A" (Argentine justice condemned crimes of Triple A)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204023507/http://www.agenciapulsar.org/nota.php?id=9290 |date=2007-02-04 }}, ''[[Agencia Pulsar]]'', 27 December 2006, URL accessed on January 4, 2007 {{es icon}}</ref>
The group is strongly suspected in the 1974 assassination of [[Jesuit]] priest [[Carlos Mugica]], a friend of [[Mario Firmenich]], the founder of Montoneros.<ref name="IPS"/> Other people murdered by the organisation include [[Silvio Frondizi]], brother of former president [[Arturo Frondizi]]; [[Julio Troxler]], former-vice director of the police; [[Alfredo Curutchet]], a defense attorney for [[political prisoner]]s; and Hipólito Atilio López, a key union leader of [[Córdoba Province, Argentina|Córdoba]]. The CONADEP commission on [[human rights]] violations documented the Triple A's execution of 19 homicides in 1973, 50 in 1974 and 359 in 1975, while its involvement in several hundred others is also suspected.
The 1986 study by Ignacio Jansen González is often cited; he estimates the group committed 220 [[terrorist]] attacks from July to September 1974, which killed 60 and severely wounded 44; as well as 20 [[kidnap]]pings.<ref>González Jansen, Ignacio (1986), ''La Triple A'', Buenos Aires, Contrapunto. {{es icon}}</ref> Federal judge [[Norberto Oyarbide]], who signed the [[extradition]] order against former leader of the AAA [[Rodolfo Almirón]], ruled in December 2006 that Triple A's crimes qualified as [[human rights violations]] and the "beginning of the systematic process directed by the state apparatus" during the [[dictatorship]].<ref name="Pulsar"/><ref name="EFE">[http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2006/12/29/internacional/1167399244.html Prisión para el ex policía argentino Rodolfo Almirón por su pertenencia a la Triple A], ''[[EFE]]'' — ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'', December 29, 2006 — URL accessed on January 4, 2007 {{es icon}}</ref>
[[Death threat]]s caused many of the opposition to leave Argentina. Amongst many well-known and respected people who left are mathematician [[Manuel Sadosky]], artists [[Héctor Alterio]], [[Luis Brandoni]] and [[Nacha Guevara]], politician and entrepreneur [[José Ber Gelbard]], lawyer and politician [[Héctor Sandler]], and actor [[Norman Briski]].<ref name="EKAPDF">[http://www.eka-partidocarlista.com/almiron.pdf "Rodolfo Almirón, de la Triple A al Montejurra"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306024855/http://www.eka-partidocarlista.com/almiron.pdf |date=2007-03-06 }}, PDF {{es icon}}</ref>
Main assassinations claimed by the AAA:
* Murder of [[Rodolfo David Ortega Peña]] on July 31, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Murder of [[Raúl Laguzzidel]] on September 5, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Murder of [[Alfredo Alberto Pérez Curutchet]] on September 10, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Kidnapping of [[Daniel Banfi]], [[Luis Latrónica]] and [[Guillermo Jabif]] on September 12, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Murder of [[Julio Tomás Troxler]] on September 20, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Murder of [[Domingo Devincenti]] on November 6, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Murders of [[Silvio Frondizi]] and his son-in-law [[Luis Ángel Mendiburu]] on September 27, 1974<ref name="EFE"/> * Murder of [[Carlos Ernensto Laham]] and [[Pedro Leopoldo Barraza]] on October 13, 1974.<ref name="EFE"/> * Murder of Ramon Samaniego on April 12, 1974<ref name="EFE"/>
==Others== After the fall of López Rega in 1975 and [[Jorge Rafael Videla]]'s [[National Reorganization Process|coup in March 1976]], many Triple A members fled to Spain, where they became involved in murders of Spanish leftists. Fifteen former AAA members (including [[Rodolfo Almirón]]) were involved in the [[Montejurra Incidents|Montejurra 1976 shooting]] of two left-wing [[Carlist]] members at a large annual gathering in Spain. Others implicated in the event were Italian neofascist Stefano Delle Chiaie and [[Jean Pierre Cherid]], former member of the French [[Organisation de l'armée secrète|OAS]] and at the time part of the [[Grupos Antiterroristas de Liberación|GAL]] death squad in Spain.<ref name="EKAPDF"/><ref>[http://www.eka-partidocarlista.com/asesinatos.htm "MONTEJURRA: LA OPERACIÓN RECONQUISTA Y EL ACTA FUNDACIONAL DE LAS TRAMAS ANTITERRORISTAS. Fuente "INTERIOR" Por Santiago Belloch"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070228193908/http://www.eka-partidocarlista.com/asesinatos.htm |date=2007-02-28 }} {{es icon}}</ref>
Former Triple A member [[José María Boccardo]] took part with Cherid and others in the 1978 assassination of [[José Miguel Beñaran Ordeñana|Argala]], the ''[[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]]'' terrorist who, in 1973, was involved in the assassination of [[Francisco Franco|Franco]]'s Prime minister [[Luis Carrero Blanco]].<ref name="Mundo">[http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2003/427/1072098707.html «Yo maté al asesino de Carrero Blanco»], ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'', 21 December 2003 {{es icon}} ([http://www.wsws.org/articles/2004/jan2004/spai-j15.shtml English account of ''El Mundo'' article])</ref>
==See also== *[[Batallón de Inteligencia 601|601 Intelligence Battalion]] *[[Alianza Americana Anticomunista]], in Colombia ([[Operation Condor]]) *[[Alianza Apostólica Anticomunista]], in Spain ([[Operation Gladio]]) *[[Montejurra Incidents]] *[[Manuel Sadosky]] and [[Héctor Alterio]] were both threatened by the AAA. *[[Rodolfo Almirón]], leader of the group and charged in several murders (arrested in Valencia 2006)
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.elmundo.es/suplementos/cronica/2006/581/1166310005.html "El 'jefe' de la Triple A vive en un arrabal de Valencia"], El Mundo, Félix Martínez y Nando García {{es icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927180021/http://www.pais-global.com.ar/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=2241 "El Debut del Terror: La Triple A"], Pablo Mendelevich {{es icon}} *[http://izquierda.info/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2899 "Triple A; Toda la verdad, caiga quien caiga"]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2010}} {{The Protocols}} '''Britons Publishing Society''', founded in 1923, was an offshoot of [[The Britons]]. According to scholar [[Gisela C. Lebzelter]], [[The Britons]] split because:
... internal disagreements proved paralysing. Seven members were excluded in November 1923, and three executives members, [[John Henry Clarke|J. H. Clarke]], the famous [[United Kingdom|British]] [[homeopath]], [[R. T. Cooper]] and [[W. A. Peters]], seceded to establish 'The Britons Publishing Society'.
On December 15, 1923 the three executed a memorandum in which they expressed their organizational purpose as follows: "propagating views in regard to the Jews, the Christian Religion, the Government of the British Isles and the British Empire, and other matters which, in our opinion from time to time, it is in the interests of the British Public should be expressed and distributed and to do anything at all which, in our opinion, equips us for this purpose. The Society to be conducted not for the purpose of making profit" == Publications == *[[British Library]] :System number 009601120 :Author - personal LinkNilus. :Title Link '''Protocols of the Meetings of the Learned Elders of Zion''' / translated from the Russian Text by Victor E. :Marsden. :Publisher/year LinkLondon: '''The Britons Publishing Society''', (1922) :Holdings (All) Details :Shelfmark W73/5522 DSC Request *'''[[Apionus]], pseud.''' :'''The bolshevists of ancient history ...''' :(London: The Britons publishing society, 1924) *'''Anonymous''' :Related names: [[Sergei Nilus|Sergi︠e︡ǐ Aleksandrovich Nilus, 1862-1929]], [[Victor E. {{Infobox film | name = La dialectique peut-elle casser des briques ? | image = La Dialectique Peut-Elle Casser Des Briques.jpg | image_size = | caption = Movie Poster | director = [[René Viénet]] | producer = | writer = | narrator = | starring = Jason Pai Piao
Chen Hung-Lieh | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = 1973 | runtime = | country = France | language = French | budget = | gross = }} '''''La dialectique peut-elle casser des briques ?''''', in English, '''''"Can [[Dialectics]] Break Bricks?"''''', is a 1973 [[Situationist International|Situationist]] film produced by the French director [[René Viénet]] which explores the development of [[class conflict]] through revolutionary agitation against a backdrop of graphic kung-fu fighting. The film uses 1972 [[martial arts film]] ''[[Crush (1972 film)|Crush]]'' by Tu Guangqi, which tells the story of anti-colonialist revolt in Korea during the period of Japanese occupation, for its visuals which has been dubbed over by the filmmakers in an attempt at [[détournement]]. The concept and motivation of this film was to adapt a "spectacular" film into a radical critique of [[cultural hegemony]] and thus into tools of subversive revolutionary ideals. The Narrative is based upon a conflict between the proletarian and bureaucrats within [[state capitalism]]. The [[proletarians]] enlist their [[dialectics]] and radical subjectivity to fight their oppressors whilst the bureaucrats defend themselves using a combination of co-optation and violence. The film is noted for its humorous approach to this serious subject matter. The film also contains many praising references to revolutionaries who thought and fought for the realisation of a post-capitalist world, including [[Marx]], [[Mikhail Bakunin|Bakunin]], and [[Wilhelm Reich]], as well as scathing criticism towards the [[French Communist Party]], [[trade unionism]] and [[Maoism]]. Also Subplots dealing with issues of [[gender equality]], [[Social alienation|alienation]], [[Paris Commune]], [[May 1968 in France|May 1968]], and the Situationist themselves are riddled throughout the film. ==External links== * [https://0xdb.org/0069970 Can Dialectics Break Bricks?] at [[0xDB]] * [http://www.ubu.com/film/vienet_dialectics.html Can Dialectics Break Bricks?] at [[UbuWeb]] * {{IMDb title|0069970}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Can Dialectics Break Bricks?}} [[Category:1973 films]] [[Category:Parody films]] [[Category:Kung fu films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Situationist International]] {{1970s-France-film-stub}}
