page.title: Creation and evolution in public education

revision.comment: /* Turkey */ Added partial line and citation.
revision.text:
{{creationism2}} {{Evolutionary biology}} The status of '''creation and evolution in public education''' has been the subject of substantial [[Creation–evolution controversy|debate]] and [[Social conflict|conflict]] in [[Law|legal]], [[Politics|political]], and [[Religion|religious]] circles. Globally, there is a wide variety of views on the topic. Most western countries have legislation that mandates only [[evolutionary biology]] is to be taught in the appropriate scientific [[syllabus]]es.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/evolution-education-abroad/|title=Evolution Abroad: Creationism Evolves in Science Classrooms around the Globe|last=Harmon|first=Katherine|date=3 March 2011|website=Scientific American|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref>
==Overview== While many doctrines do not raise theological objections to the modern evolutionary synthesis as an explanation for the present form of life on Earth, various [[fundamentalism|fundamentalist]] sects, including many churches within [[Christianity]], have objected vehemently.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/ev_publi.htm |title=Beliefs of the U.S. public about evolution and creation |last=Robinson |first=Bruce A. |date=November 1995 |website=ReligiousTolerance.org |publisher=[[Ontario Consultants on Religious Tolerance]] |location=Kingston, Ontario |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> Some adherents are passionately opposed to the [[Scientific consensus|consensus]] view of the [[scientific community]]. [[Literal and figurative language|Literal]] interpretations of religious texts are the greatest cause of conflict with evolutionary and [[cosmology|cosmological]] investigations and conclusions.
Internationally, evolution is taught in science courses with limited controversy, with the exception of a few areas of the [[United States]] and several [[Islam]]ic fundamentalist countries. In the United States, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] has ruled the teaching of [[creationism]] as [[science]] in [[State school#United States|public schools]] to be unconstitutional, irrespective of how it may be purveyed in [[Theology|theological]] or [[Catechism|religious instruction]]. In the United States, [[intelligent design]] (ID) has been represented as an alternative explanation to evolution in recent decades, but its "demonstrably religious, cultural, and legal missions" have been ruled unconstitutional by a [[United States district court|lower court]].<ref name="Saletan">{{cite journal |last=Saletan |first=William |authorlink=William Saletan |date=December 21, 2005 |title=Is Creationism Destructible? |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/human_nature/2005/12/is_creationism_destructible.html |journal=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=[[Graham Holdings Company|The Washington Post Company]] |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref><ref name="Witt_2006">{{cite web |url=http://www.evolutionnews.org/2006/09/science_magazine_reviews_the_l002664.html |title=Science magazine reviews The Language of God by Francis Collins, Ignores the Book's Intelligent Design |last=Witt |first=Jonathan |date=September 29, 2006 |website=Evolution News & Views |publisher=[[Discovery Institute]] |location=Seattle, WA |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref><ref name="CB">{{cite web |url=http://www.criminalbrief.com/?p=798| title=Evilution |last=Lundin |first=Leigh |date=May 4, 2008 |website=Criminal Brief |publisher=CriminalBrief.com |location=Los Angeles, CA |accessdate=2010-03-05}}</ref><ref name="Annas_2006">{{cite journal |last=Annas |first=George J. |authorlink=George Annas |date=May 25, 2006 |title=Intelligent Judging — Evolution in the Classroom and the Courtroom |url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMlim055660 |journal=[[The New England Journal of Medicine]] |location=Waltham, MA |publisher=[[Massachusetts Medical Society]] |volume=354 |pages=2277–2281 |doi=10.1056/NEJMlim055660 |accessdate=2014-06-15 |pmid=16723620 |issue=21}}</ref>
==By country==
===Australia=== Although creationist views are popular among [[religious education]] teachers and creationist teaching materials have been distributed by volunteers in some schools,<ref>{{cite news |last=Minus |first=Jodie |date=June 25, 2010 |title=Creationism creeps into NSW schools |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/creationism-creeps-into-nsw-schools/story-e6frg6nf-1225884487850 |newspaper=[[The Australian]] |location=Sydney |publisher=[[News Corp Australia]] |accessdate=2011-02-26}}</ref> many Australian [[scientist]]s take an aggressive stance supporting the right of teachers to teach the theory of evolution, unhindered by religious restrictions.
{{cquote| An essential element in the teaching of science is the encouragement of students and teachers to critically appraise the evidence for notions being taught as science. The Society states unequivocally that the dogmatic teaching of notions such as Creationism within a science curriculum stifles the development of critical thinking patterns in the developing mind and seriously compromises the best interests of objective public education. This could eventually hamper the advancement of science and technology as students take their places as leaders of future generations. |||[[Geological Society of Australia]]<ref name="GSA">{{cite web |url=http://www.gsa.org.au/pdfdocuments/management/POL_intel%20design_2008.pdf |title=Intelligent Design Policy: Science Education and Creationism |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=December 17, 2008 |website=Geological Society of Australia |publisher=[[Geological Society of Australia|Geological Society of Australia Incorporated]] |location=Sydney |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref>}}
===Brazil=== In [[Brazil]], teaching of creationism in scientific education classes is forbidden by the [[Ministry of Education (Brazil)|Ministry of Education]] (MEC).<ref>{{cite news |last1=Takahashi |first1=Fábio |last2=Bedinelli |first2=Talita |date=December 13, 2008 |title=MEC diz que criacionismo não é tema para aula de ciências |trans-title=MEC says that creationism is not subject for science class |url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/educacao/2008/12/478968-mec-diz-que-criacionismo-nao-e-tema-para-aula-de-ciencias.shtml |newspaper=[[Folha de S.Paulo]] |language=Portuguese |location=São Paulo |publisher=[[Grupo Folha]] |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref> Religious education is not forbidden as such, but the federal constitution states that the union can neither impose, nor promote, nor finance any religion, because by law Brazil is a [[secular state]].<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2010 |title=Constitution of the Federative Republic of Brazil |url=http://english.tse.jus.br/arquivos/federal-constitution |format=PDF |series=Textos básicos |issue=n. 57 |others=Translation by Istvan Vajda, Patricia de Queiroz Carvalho Zimbres, and Vanira Tavares de Souza |edition=3rd |location=Brasília |publisher=Documentation and Information Center; Publishing Coordination; [[Chamber of Deputies (Brazil)|Chamber of Deputies]] |page=29 |isbn=978-85-736-5736-4 |oclc=705932082}} See Title III, Chapter 1, Article 19.</ref> In 2004 however, teachers of religious education classes in schools of the education department of [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] began to present creationism in their classes as scientific fact. The practice was directly initiated by politicians in power who were promoting their personal religious views, and their action moved Brazilian scientists to protest the abuse.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gazir |first=Augusto |date=May 13, 2004 |title=Escolas do Rio vão ensinar criacionismo |trans-title=Schools of Rio will teach creationism |url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/ciencia/ult306u11748.shtml |newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo |language=Portuguese |location=São Paulo |publisher=Grupo Folha |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref><ref name="MacKenzie" /> Subsequently, in congress a "religious bench," or faction, has become increasingly influential.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.revistaovies.com/reportagens/2011/12/um-estado-laico-com-bancada-evangelica/ |title=Um estado laico com bancada evangélica |trans-title=A secular state with evangelical bench |last=Severo |first=Felipe |date=December 12, 2011 |website=revista o Viés |language=Portuguese |type=Blog |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref> For example, a Brazilian senator, [[Marcelo Crivella]], the former [[:pt:Ministério da Pesca e Aquicultura|Minister of Fishing and Aquiculture]], publicly declared his religiously founded antagonism to evolution.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.senado.gov.br/atividade/plenario/sessao/disc/getTexto.asp?s=004.3.53.O&disc=183/1/S |title=Senado Federal: Secretaria-Geral da Mesa: Secretaria de Taquigrafia e Redação de Debates Legislativos |date=February 10, 2009 |website=Senado Federal |publisher=[[Federal Senate]] |location=Brasília |language=Portuguese |accessdate=2014-06-15}} *{{cite AV media |last=Crivella |first=Marcelo |authorlink=Marcelo Crivella |date=February 10, 2009 |title=Criacionista, Crivella filosofa sobre origem da ameba |trans-title=Creationist, Crivella philosophical about the origin of the amoeba |language=Portuguese |url=http://mais.uol.com.br/view/12574020 |format=Adobe Flash Video |location=São Paulo |publisher=[[Universo Online|UOL]] |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref> Such prominent influences have drawn the attention of the defenders of the secular state.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Coutinho |first=Simone Andréa Barcelos |date=August 23, 2011 |title=Escolha eleitoral deve considerar secularismo do Estado |trans-title=Electoral choice should consider secularism of the State |url=http://www.conjur.com.br/2011-ago-23/escolha-membros-poder-levar-conta-secularismo-estatal |journal=Consultor Jurídico |location=São Paulo |language=Portuguese |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref>
===Council of Europe=== ;Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe Resolution 1580
On October 4, 2007, the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE) adopted its Resolution 1580 titled ''The dangers of creationism in education''. The resolution observed that "The war on the theory of evolution and on its proponents most often originates in forms of religious extremism closely linked to extreme right-wing political movements," and urged member states "firmly oppose the teaching of creationism as a scientific discipline on an equal footing with the theory of evolution and in general the presentation of creationist ideas in any discipline other than religion."<ref name="PACE_2007-10-04">{{cite web |url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/X2H-Xref-ViewHTML.asp?FileID=11751&lang=en |title=The dangers of creationism in education |date=October 4, 2007 |work=Committee on Culture, Science and Education |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |type=Resolution |id=Resolution 1580 |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/X2H-Xref-ViewHTML.asp?FileID=11751&lang=en ;Drafting and adoption
The Assembly's work leading to adopting the resolution began in 2006, when several delegates of the assembly, led by British [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] politician [[Andrew McIntosh, Baron McIntosh of Haringey|Andrew McIntosh]], suggested to adopt a recommendation on this theme.<ref name="EDOC11065">{{cite web |url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/X2H-Xref-ViewHTML.asp?FileID=11416&lang=EN |title=The dangers of creationism in education |date=October 4, 2006 |work=Committee on Culture, Science and Education |publisher=[[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] |type=Motion for a recommendation |id=Doc. 11065 |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> During drafting, the report and draft resolution<ref name="EDOC11297">{{cite web |url=http://www.assembly.coe.int/ASP/Doc/XrefViewHTML.asp?FileID=11678&Language=EN |title=The dangers of creationism in education |date=June 8, 2007 |work=Committee on Culture, Science and Education |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |type=Report |id=Doc. 11297 |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> were prepared by the delegate from the French [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist Party]], [[:fr:Guy Lengagne|Guy Lengagne]].
The report was returned by PACE to its Committee on Culture, Science and Education for revision in June 2007 with 63 votes against 46,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lifesitenews.com/news/proposed-council-of-europe-report-calls-creationism-dangerousthreat-to-huma |title=Proposed Council of Europe Report Calls Creationism 'Dangerous,' 'Threat to Human Rights' |last=White |first=Hilary |date=June 27, 2007 |website=LifeSiteNews.com |publisher=[[Campaign Life Coalition]] |location=Toronto, Ontario |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> at the request by the leader of the [[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|Christian Democratic]] group in the Assembly [[Luc Van den Brande]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/Records/2007/E/0706251130E.htm |title=2007 Ordinary Session: (Third part): Report: Nineteenth Sitting: Monday 25 June 2007 at 11.30 a.m. |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |type=Verbatim record |id=AACR19 / AS (2007) CR 19 |accessdate=2014-06-16}} Verbatim record of the PACE sitting on June 25, 2007 - see para. 7.</ref> [[Reuters]] noted that calling off the debate and vote "also won support from east European deputies,{{which|date=February 2014}} who recalled that Darwinian evolution was a favorite theory of their former communist rulers."<ref>{{cite news |last=Reilhac |first=Gilbert |date=June 25, 2007 |title=European rights body calls off creationism vote |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2007/06/25/life-europe-creationism-dc-idUKL2543885120070625 |agency=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> The procedure used for the referral was criticized by the Assembly's Committee on Culture, Science and Education.<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=June 26, 2007 |title=Statement by PACE's Committee on Culture, Science and Education, 26 June 2007 |url=http://assembly.coe.int/asp/apfeaturesmanager/defaultArtView.asp?ID=686 |journal=PACE News |location=Strasbourg |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> After the revision by a new [[rapporteur]], [[Anne Brasseur]], a delegate from Luxembourg representing the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|Liberal]] group in the Assembly<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.assembly.coe.int/ASP/Doc/XrefViewHTML.asp?FileID=11751&Language=EN |title=The dangers of creationism in education |date=September 17, 2007 |work=Committee on Culture, Science and Education |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |type=Report |id=Doc. 11375 |accessdate=2014-06-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307233347/http://assembly.coe.int/ASP/Doc/XrefViewHTML.asp?FileID=11751&Language=en |archivedate=2013-03-07 |df= }}</ref> and several amendments made by the Assembly, the resolution was adopted, by 48 votes against 25.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://assembly.coe.int//Main.asp?link=http://assembly.coe.int/Documents/PV/2007/0710041500E.htm |title=2007 Ordinary Session: (Fourth part): Thirty-fifth Sitting: Thursday 4 October 2007 at 3 p.m.: Minutes of Proceedings |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |type=Minutes |id=AS (2007) PV 35 |accessdate=2014-06-16}} Minutes of the PACE sitting on October 4, 2007. *{{cite web |url=http://assembly.coe.int/ASP/Votes/DBVotesResults_EN.asp?VoteID=664&DocID=12120&SessionID=221 |title=Voting results (Participants) |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004172202/http://assembly.coe.int/ASP/Votes/DBVotesResults_EN.asp?VoteID=664&DocID=12120&SessionID=221 |archivedate=2011-10-04 |accessdate=2014-06-16}} Voting results on the amendments and resolution ("The dangers of creationism in education" (Doc. 11375)). Vote on resolution: In favour: 48; against: 25; abstention: 3.</ref>
;Content The resolution's aim is "to warn against certain tendencies to pass off a belief as science … the Parliamentary Assembly is worried about the possible ill-effect of the spread of creationist ideas within our education systems and about the consequences for our democracies. If we are not careful, creationism could become a threat to human rights."<ref name="dw-world.de">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Council of Europe: Keep Creationism Out of Science Classes |url=http://www.dw.de/council-of-europe-keep-creationism-out-of-science-classes/a-2809619 |work=[[Deutsche Welle]] |location=Berlin/Bonn, Germany |publisher=[[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] |date=October 5, 2007 |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref> It rejects that creationism in any form, including "intelligent design," can be considered scientific (Para. 4), but considers possible its inclusion in religion and cultural classes (Para. 16). The resolution concludes that teaching creationism in school as a scientific theory may threaten civil rights (Paras. 13 and 18). The resolution summarizes itself in Para. 19:<ref name="PACE_2007-10-04" /> {{quotation| The Parliamentary Assembly therefore urges the member states, and especially their education authorities to: #defend and promote scientific knowledge; #strengthen the teaching of the foundations of science, its history, its epistemology and its methods alongside the teaching of objective scientific knowledge; #make science more comprehensible, more attractive and closer to the realities of the contemporary world; #firmly oppose the teaching of creationism as a scientific discipline on an equal footing with the theory of evolution and in general the presentation of creationist ideas in any discipline other than religion; #promote the teaching of evolution as a fundamental scientific theory in the school curricula.}}
;Coverage and reaction
<!-- Before adopting the resolution, the report prepared by Lengagne was criticised by the [[European Center for Law and Justice]].<ref>[http://media.aclj.org/pdf/eclj_memo_coe_dangers_creationism_education_07052007.pdf Memorandum on Council of Europe legislation, Draft Resoluion Regarding Report on "The Dangers of Creationism in Education"] [[European Center for Law and Justice]], 2007</ref> -->After the rejection of Lengagne's report, the former rapporteur was interviewed on the subject by the French newspaper ''[[20 minutes (France)|20 Minutes]]'', where he evaluated the events as follows: "We are witnessing a return to the Middle Ages."<ref>{{cite interview |last=Lengagne |first=Guy |authorlink=:fr:Guy Lengagne |interviewer=''20 Minutes'' |title='Le Conseil de l'Europe cède à des religieux intégristes' |trans-title=The Council of Europe yields to religious fundamentalists |language=French |url=http://www.20minutes.fr/france/167016-conseil-europe-cede-a-religieux-integristes |newspaper=[[20 minutes (France)|20 Minutes]] |location=Oslo, Norway |publisher=[[Schibsted]] |date=June 27, 2007 |accessdate=2014-06-16}}</ref>
The resolution was criticised by deputy head of the Department for External Church Relations of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], [[Archpriest]] [[:ru:Чаплин, Всеволод Анатольевич|Vsevolod Chaplin]], stating that "those few fossils presented by the anthropologists as examples of ape-human transitional forms could be explained by random mutations. We don't claim to found a new species upon finding a fish with two heads."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pravoslavie.ru/news/24362.htm |script-title=ru:В Русской Православной Церкви критикуют резолюцию ПАСЕ, направленную против креационизма |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=October 12, 2007 |website=[[:ru:Православие.Ru|Православие.Ru]] |location=Moscow |language=Russian |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> and by the president of [[Southern Baptist Theological Seminary]] [[Albert Mohler]] considering that "this can only mean that Europe (at least as represented by the Council of Europe) has forgotten even its Christian memory."<ref>{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Lawrence |date=October 10, 2007 |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/evangelical-theologian-disputes-creationism-s-alleged-threat-to-human-rights-29644/ |title=Evangelical Theologian Disputes Creationism's Alleged 'Threat' to Human Rights |work=[[The Christian Post]] |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=The Christian Post, Inc. |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
In February 2009, the resolution was a starting point of a conference held in [[Dortmund|Dortmund, Germany]], and led by Dittmar Graf from the [[Dortmund University of Technology]]. The conference, including participation of Anne Brasseur, among others, was held in cooperation with the [[Max Planck Institute for Molecular Physiology]], [[University of Vienna]] and [[Hacettepe University]] and with support from German [[Federal Ministry of Education and Research (Germany)|Ministry of Education and Research]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hemminger |first=Hansjörg |authorlink=:de:Hansjörg Hemminger |date=April 2009 |title=Einstellungen zu Evolution und Wissenschaft in Europa |url=http://www.ekd.de/ezw/Publikationen_berichte_einstellungen_zu_evolution.php |journal=Materialdienst |language=German |location=Berlin |publisher=[[Evangelical Church in Germany]] |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
Michael Poole, a [[King's College London]] Visiting Research Fellow in Science and Religion and a founding member of the [[International Society for Science and Religion]], criticised the resolution for being too restrictive while disapproving of [[young Earth creationism]] and the [[intelligent design movement]].<ref name="Poole_2008">{{cite journal |last=Poole |first=Michael |date=September 2008 |title=Creationism, intelligent design and science education |url=http://www.issr.org.uk/documents/SSR_Sept_2008_Poole.pdf |format=PDF |journal=[[The Association for Science Education#Journals|School Science Review]] |location=London |publisher=[[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]] |volume=90 |issue=330 |pages=123–129 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929020848/http://www.issr.org.uk/documents/SSR_Sept_2008_Poole.pdf |archivedate=2011-09-29 |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
[[Deutsche Welle]], covering the disagreement among members of the Assembly on whether the resolution constituted an attack on religious beliefs,<ref name="dw-world.de"/> and ''[[Die Welt]]'', pointing to journalists-expressed suspicions of wishing to limit freedom of conscience and Brasseur's response that the aim was to draw a line between the spheres of faith and science.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Europäisches Gremium verurteilt Kreationismus |url=https://www.welt.de/politik/article1236940/Europaeisches-Gremium-verurteilt-Kreationismus.html |newspaper=[[Die Welt]] |language=German |location=Berlin |publisher=[[Axel Springer AG|Axel Springer SE]] |date=October 5, 2007 |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
===Denmark=== On April 25, 2007, Member of Parliament [[:da:Martin Henriksen|Martin Henriksen]] ([[Danish People's Party]]) asked [[Education Minister of Denmark|Education Minister]] [[Bertel Haarder]] ([[Venstre (Denmark)|Liberal Party of Denmark]]) for information about how many educational institutions had received ''[[The Atlas of Creation]]'' (2006) by [[Adnan Oktar|Harun Yahya]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.dk/Samling/20061/spoergsmaal/S4310/index.htm |title=§ 20-spørgsmål S 4310 Om bogen »Atlas of Creation« |last=Henriksen |first=Martin |authorlink=:da:Martin Henriksen |date=April 25, 2007 |website=Folketinget |publisher=[[Folketing|The Danish Parliament]] |location=Copenhagen, Kingdom of Denmark |language=Danish |trans-title=§ 20-question S 4310 About the book 'Atlas of Creation' |accessdate=2014-06-19}} *{{cite news |last=Hall |first=Ole |date=April 24, 2007 |title=Muslimsk offensiv mod Darwin |trans-title=Muslim offensive against Darwin |url=http://jyllands-posten.dk/indland/ECE5028710/muslimsk-offensiv-mod-darwin/ |newspaper=[[Jyllands-Posten]] |language=Danish |location=Viby J |publisher=[[JP/Politikens Hus]] |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> The minister responded that the Ministry of Education was not in possession of information about the number of educational institutions that had received the book. Further, he stated that the choice of educational materials is decided by local school boards. Moreover, it is his view that the end goal of primary school biology instruction is to enable students to acquire the knowledge and skills needed to explain the basic elements of [[heredity]] and evolution and to address the issues related to the biological coursework.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.dk/samling/20061/spoergsmaal/s4310/svar/332659/372118.pdf |title=Undervisningsminister Bertel Haarders skriftlige svar til medlem af Folketinget Martin Henriksen (DF) på spørgsmål af 25. april 2007 nr. S 4310 |last=Haarders |first=Bertel |authorlink=Bertel Haarder |date=May 9, 2007 |website=Folketinget |publisher=The Danish Parliament |location=Copenhagen, Kingdom of Denmark |language=Danish |trans-title=Education Minister Bertel Haarder written reply to a Member of Parliament Martin Henriksen (DF) questions of 25 April 2007 No. S 4310 |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
In interview sessions during 2002, less than 10% of the interviewed Danes declared the theory of evolution as being definitely false.<ref name="Public_Acceptance">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jon D. |last2=Scott |first2=Eugenie C. |authorlink2=Eugenie Scott |last3=Okamoto |first3=Shinji |date=August 11, 2006 |title=Public Acceptance of Evolution |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] |volume=313 |issue=5788 |pages=765–766 |doi=10.1126/science.1126746 |pmid=16902112}}<!--|accessdate=2014-06-19 --> [http://www.sciencemag.org/content/suppl/2006/08/08/313.5788.765.DC1/Miller.SOM.pdf "Supporting Online Material for Public Acceptance of Evolution"] (PDF).</ref>
===Iran=== [[Iran]]ian [[Science and technology in Iran|scientific development]], especially the health-related aspects of [[biology]], has been a goal of the Islamic government since the [[Iranian Revolution]] of 1979.<ref name="BurtonIRNKSA">{{cite journal |last=Burton |first=Elise K. |date=May–June 2010 |title=Teaching Evolution in Muslim States:Iran and Saudi Arabia Compared |url=http://xa.yimg.com/kq/groups/19234639/1613108208/name/Iran%20and%20Saudi%20Arabia%20Compared.pdf|journal=Reports of the National Center for Science Education |location=Berkeley, CA |publisher=[[National Center for Science Education]] |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=25–29 |accessdate=2014-01-13}}</ref> Since Iranian traditional practice of [[Shia Islam|Shi'a]] religion isn't preoccupied with [[Quran|Qur'anic]] literalism as in case of fundamentalist [[Wahhabi movement|Wahhabism]] but [[ijtihad]], many influential Iranian Shi'ite scholars, including several who were closely involved in the Iranian Revolution, are not opposed to evolutionary ideas in general, disagreeing that evolution necessarily conflicts with the [[Muslim]] mainstream.<ref name="BurtonIRNKSA" /> Evolution is incorporated in the science curriculum starting from the 5th grade. An emphasis is placed on empirical evidence, such as the study of fossils, rather than Islamic scripture, thus portraying [[geologist]]s and other types of scientists as the authoritative voices of scientific knowledge.<ref name="BurtonIRNKSA" />
===Netherlands=== In the [[Netherlands]] some factions teach creationism in their own schools, besides evolution.<ref>Stefaan Blancke en Abraham C. Flipse, [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/312187402_The_Low_Countries The Low Countries], in: 'Creationism in Europe, red. Stefaan Blancke, Hans Henrik Hjermitslev and Peter C Kjærgaard (Medicin, science, and religion in historical context, Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2014), 65-84.'</ref> In May 2005, a discussion on intelligent design erupted when [[Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (Netherlands)|Minister of Education]] [[Maria van der Hoeven]] suggested that debate about intelligent design might encourage discourse between the country's various religious groups. She sought to "stimulate an academic debate" on the subject. Following strong objection from some scientists,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Enserink |first=Martin |date=June 3, 2005 |title=Is Holland Becoming the Kansas of Europe? |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/308/5727/1394.2.summary |journal=Science |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |volume=308 |issue=5727 |page=1394 |doi=10.1126/science.308.5727.1394b |pmid=15933170}}</ref> she dropped plans of holding a conference on the matter.<ref name="MacKenzie" /> After the [[Dutch general election, 2007|2007 elections]], she was succeeded by [[Ronald Plasterk]], described as a "molecular geneticist, staunch atheist and opponent of intelligent design."<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Cabinet ministers announced (update 2) |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2007/02/cabinet_ministers_announced_up.php |work=DutchNews.nl |location=Amsterdam |publisher=Dutch News BV |date=February 13, 2007 |accessdate=2008-05-31}}</ref>
===Norway=== In 1986, Norway's then-[[Ministry of Education and Research (Norway)|Minister of Church and Education Affairs]] [[Kjell Magne Bondevik]] proposed new education plans for the elementary and middle school levels which included skepticism to the theory of evolution and would hold that a final answer to the origin of mankind was unknown. The proposal was withdrawn after it had generated controversy.<ref>{{cite news |last=Meldalen |first=Sindre Granly |date=February 1, 2009 |title=Halvparten av britene tror ikke på dette |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/02/01/nyheter/innnenriks/forskning/darwin/4641873/ |newspaper=[[Dagbladet]] |language=Norwegian |location=Copenhagen, Kingdom of Denmark |publisher=[[Aller Media]] |accessdate=2009-09-09}}</ref>
===Pakistan=== Although it has been claimed that evolution is not taught in [[Pakistan]]i universities;<ref name="MacKenzie">{{cite journal |last=MacKenzie |first=Debora |date=July 9, 2005 |title=Creationism special: A battle for science's soul |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn7647-creationism-special-a-battle-for-sciences-soul.html?full=true |journal=[[New Scientist]] |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |volume=187 |issue=2507 |pages=8–9 |accessdate=2014-06-15 |quote=Eighty years after the Scopes trial drew the battle lines over evolution and creationism, Darwin's theory is under renewed attack, this time from 'intelligent design'. It's an idea that is spreading into US culture and beyond.}}</ref> the [[Higher Education Commission of Pakistan]], which is the federal body which sets standards of course content, has knowledge and understanding of evolution as being compulsory for several courses such as [[microbiology]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hec.gov.pk/InsideHEC/Divisions/AECA/CurriculumRevision/Documents/Micro%20Biology%202008.pdf |title=Curriculum of Microbiology BS (4-Year) |last=Ali |first=Zulfiqar |others=Preface by Riaz-ul-Haq Tariq |year=2008 |website=Higher Education Commission, Pakistan |publisher=[[Higher Education Commission of Pakistan]] |location=Islamabad |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> [[bioinformatics]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hec.gov.pk/InsideHEC/Divisions/AECA/CurriculumRevision/Documents/Bioinformatics-2010.pdf |title=Curriculum of Bioinformatics BS MS |last=Ali |first=Zulfiqar |others=Preface by Muhammad Javed Khan |year=2011 |website=Higher Education Commission, Pakistan |publisher=Higher Education Commission of Pakistan |location=Islamabad |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> [[zoology]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hec.gov.pk/InsideHEC/Divisions/AECA/CurriculumRevision/Documents/Zoology%202008.pdf |title=Curriculum of Zoology BS (4-Year) |others=Preface by Riaz-ul-Haq Tariq |year=2008 |website=Higher Education Commission, Pakistan |publisher=Higher Education Commission of Pakistan |location=Islamabad |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> [[botany]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hec.gov.pk/InsideHEC/Divisions/AECA/CurriculumRevision/Documents/Draft-Botany-2012-13.pdf |title=Curriculum of Botany BS (4-Year) & MS/MPhil |last=Ali |first=Zulfiqar |others=Preface by Fida Hussain |year=2013 |website=Higher Education Commission, Pakistan |publisher=Higher Education Commission of Pakistan |location=Islamabad |type=Draft |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> as well as others. In 2006, the [[Pakistan Academy of Sciences]] became a signatory of the [[InterAcademy Panel]] Statement on "The teaching of evolution."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.interacademies.net/10878/13901.aspx |title=IAP Statement on the Teaching of Evolution |author=IAP Member Academies |date=June 21, 2006 |website=[[InterAcademy Panel|IAP]] |publisher=[[TWAS|The World Academy of Sciences]] |location=Trieste, Italy |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> Many of the contemporary titles on the [[creation-evolution controversy]], such as those by [[biologist]] [[Richard Dawkins]], are available for general sale.<ref>Titles such as ''[[The Blind Watchmaker]]'' (1986) by [[Richard Dawkins]] are also available for [http://mashalbooks.org/?page_id=392 general readership].</ref>
===Poland=== [[Poland]] saw a controversy over creationism in 2006 when Deputy Education Minister [[Mirosław Orzechowski]] denounced evolution as a lie taught in Polish schools. His superior, [[Ministry of National Education (Poland)|Minister of National Education]] [[Roman Giertych]], has stated that the theory of evolution would continue to be taught in Polish schools, "as long as most scientists in our country say that it is the right theory." Giertych's father, [[Member of the European Parliament]] [[Maciej Giertych]], has however opposed the teaching of evolution and has claimed that "in every culture there are indications that we remember [[dinosaur]]s. The Scots have [[Loch Ness Monster|Nessie]]; we Poles have the [[Wawel Dragon|Wawel dragon]]."<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=December 18, 2006 |title=And finally... |url=http://www.wbj.pl/?command=article&id=35336&type=wbj |newspaper=[[Warsaw Business Journal]] |location=Warsaw, Poland |publisher=Valkea Media |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
===Romania=== In 1998, Ioan Moisin, a [[Christian Democratic National Peasants' Party|Christian Democratic]] senator and a Greek Catholic priest, called upon [[Romania]]'s [[Ministry of Education, Research, Youth and Sport (Romania)|Ministry of Education]] to establish a commission of Catholics who would revise biology textbooks and philosophical textbooks to not contradict [[Bible|Biblical]] creationism. Moisin disapproved of students learning from their religious teachers that [[God]] created [[Human|human beings]] and then learning to the contrary from biology and philosophy teachers that humans descend from [[ape]]s as a product of evolution by Darwinian [[natural selection]]. Moisin's proposal to establish the commission also sought to form a Council of Public Morality that would feature representatives composed of teachers and clergy, to oversee public education, and to be subordinated only to the direct authority of the [[President of Romania]]. Romania's [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] and Ministry of Education never seriously considered the latter proposals.<ref name="Stan & Turcescu 2005">{{cite journal |last1=Stan |first1=Lavinia |authorlink1=Lavinia Stan |last2=Turcescu |first2=Lucian |authorlink2=Lucian Turcescu |date=September 2005 |title=Religious education in Romania |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967067X0500036X |journal=Communist and Post-Communist Studies |location=Oxford |publisher=[[Butterworth-Heinemann]] |volume=38 |issue=6 |pages=381–401 |doi=10.1016/j.postcomstud.2005.06.007 |accessdate=2012-08-07}}</ref> However, starting the year 2006 and ongoing{{When|date=December 2017}} Darwinian evolution was discontinued from newly printed school books throughout the country without being reintroduced.<ref name="hotnews.ro [in Romanian]">{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-2456107-cum-batut-europenii-americanii-pentru-darwin-dumnezeu.htm |title=Cum s-au batut europenii si americanii pentru Darwin si Dumnezeu [How Europeans and the US fought for Darwin and god] |date=February 27, 2008 |accessdate=2017-12-23}}</ref><ref name="contributors.ro [in Romanian]">{{cite web |url=http://www.contributors.ro/administratie/educatie/teoria-evolutiei-trebuie-sa-se-predea-din-nou-in-scolile-din-romania/ |title=Teoria evoluţiei trebuie să se predea din nou în şcolile din România [Evolution must be taught again in Romanian schools] |date=January 23, 2015 |accessdate=2017-12-23}}></ref>
===Russia=== In December 2006, a schoolgirl in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]], and her father took the issue of the teaching of evolution in Russian schools to court. The [[Russian Ministry of Education]] supports the theory of evolution. Representatives of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] backed the suit.<ref>{{cite news |last=Niedowski |first=Erika |date=January 3, 2007 |title= In Russia, a test of God vs. Darwin |url= http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2007-01-03/news/0701030102_1_darwin-theory-theory-of-evolution-charles-darwin |newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |location=Chicago, IL |publisher =[[Tribune Company]] |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Leonov | first=Maksim |date=March 1, 2006 |title=St. Petersburg schoolgirl sues authorities over Darwinism |url=http://en.ria.ru/russia/20060301/43853593.html |location=Moscow |agency= [[RIA Novosti]] |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> In February 2007, the first instance court, and in July, the second instance court, ruled in favour of the Ministry.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | script-title=ru:Суд Санкт-Петербурга отклонил иск о преподавании теории Дарвина |url=http://ria.ru/society/20070704/68336516.html | location=Moscow |agency=RIA Novosti |language=Russian |date=July 4, 2007 |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref>
In August 2014 the Mayor of [[Kazan]], [[Ilsur Metshin|Il'sur Metshin]], expressed surprise at schools teaching the "theory of Darwin".<ref>{{cite news | script-title=ru:Мэр Казани отвергает теорию Дарвина | url=http://www.evening-kazan.ru/news/mer-kazani-otvergaet-teoriyu-darvina.html | newspaper =Вечерняя Казань | language =Russian | publication-date=2014-08-21 | accessdate =2014-08-25 | quote =Выступая сегодня на городской конференции педагогов, казанский градоначальник Ильсур Метшин высказал удивление по поводу того, что в школах до сих пор преподают теорию Дарвина о происхождении человека}}</ref> He added that he intended to raise the question of the school curriculum at the federal level.<ref>{{cite news| script-title=ru:Мэр Казани предлагает запретить теорию Дарвина | trans-title =The Mayor of Kazan' plans to forbid Darwin's theory| url =http://www.otr-online.ru/news/news_32967.html| newspaper =Общественное телевидение России| language =Russian| location =Moscow| publisher =Общественное телевидение России| publication-date=2014-08-23| accessdate =2014-08-25| quote =Он добавил, что планирует поднять вопрос о необходимости преподавания в школах теории Дарвина на федеральном уровне}}</ref>
===Saudi Arabia=== A Saudi 12th-grade textbook mentions evolution by name only where it claims that Charles Darwin has "denied [[Allah]]'s creation of humanity".<ref name="BurtonIRNKSA" /> The rest of the textbook focuses on descriptions of the taxonomic ranks: it makes no further mention of evolution, only quoting Qur'an verses as relevant to certain groups of animals.<ref name="BurtonIRNKSA" />
===Serbia=== In [[Serbia]] the teaching of evolution was suspended for one week in 2004, under [[Cabinet of Serbia (2004–07)|Minister of Education and Sport]] [[Ljiljana Čolić]], only allowing schools to reintroduce evolution into the curriculum if they also taught creationism.<ref>{{cite news |last=de Quetteville |first=Harry |date=September 9, 2004 |title=Darwin is off the curriculum for Serbian schools |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1471367/Darwin-is-off-the-curriculum-for-Serbian-schools.html |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> "After a deluge of protest from scientists, teachers and opposition parties" says the [[BBC]] report, Čolić's deputy, Milan Brdar, made the statement, "I have come here to confirm [[Charles Darwin]] is still alive" and announced that the decision was reversed.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=September 9, 2004 |title=Serbia reverses Darwin suspension |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3642460.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |location=London |publisher=[[BBC]] |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> Čolić resigned after the government said that she had caused "problems that had started to reflect on the work of the entire government."<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=September 16, 2004 |title='Anti-Darwin' Serb minister quits |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3663196.stm |work=BBC News |location=London |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref>
===Turkey=== In [[Turkey]], a country where the majority of population is Muslim, evolution is often a controversial subject. Evolution was added to the school curriculum shortly after the [[Turkish War of Independence|Turkish Revolution]] of the 1920s and 30s.<ref name="Edis">{{cite journal |last=Edis |first=Taner |authorlink=Taner Edis |date=January 2008 |title=Islamic Creationism: A Short History |url=http://www.hssonline.org/publications/Newsletter2008/NewsletterJanuary2008Creationism.html |journal=Newsletter |location=Notre Dame, IN |publisher=[[History of Science Society]] |volume=37 |issue=1 |issn=0739-4934 |accessdate=2008-02-24 |quote=...Islam has been the world religion that has proved most resistant to Darwinian evolution. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716061337/http://www.hssonline.org/publications/Newsletter2008/NewsletterJanuary2008Creationism.html |archivedate=2011-07-16 |df= }}</ref> There was some resistance to this, such as that of [[Said Nursî]] and his followers, but opposition was not particularly powerful.<ref name="Edis" /> In fact, some prominent Turkish scholars during the first decades of the new-born Turkish republic, such as [[:tr:Ahmet Hamdi Akseki|Ahmet Hamdi Akseki]] (d. 1951), who once served as the [[Presidency of Religious Affairs|President of Religious Affairs of Turkey]], and İzmirli İsmail Hakkı (d. 1946) thought that the theory of evolution cannot be seen as contrary to Islam because it was already to be found in the classical works of Muslim theology.<ref name=VKaya>{{cite journal |last=Kaya |first=Veysel |date=April 2012 |title=Can the Quran Support Darwin? An Evolutionist Approach by Two Turkish Scholars after the Foundation of the Turkish Republic |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1478-1913.2011.01362.x/abstract |journal=The Muslim World |volume=102 |issue=2 |pages=357–370 |doi=10.1111/j.1478-1913.2011.01362.x |issn=1478-1913 |accessdate=2013-03-08}}</ref> In the 1980s, conservatives came into power, and used the ideas of [[Creation science|scientific creationists]] in the [[United States|US]] as a method of discrediting evolution (notwithstanding material on the [[age of the Earth]], which [[Islamic views on evolution|Islamic creationism]] is less specific about).
One anti-evolutionist group in Turkey is the [[Istanbul]] based ''[[:tr:Bilim Araştırma Vakfı|Bilim Araştırma Vakfı]]'' (BAV), or "Science Research Foundation," which was founded by [[Adnan Oktar]] in 1990. Its activities include campaigns against the teaching of evolution. It has been described as one of the strongest anti-evolution organizations outside of [[North America]].<ref name=Koenig>{{cite journal |last=Koenig |first=Robert |date=May 18, 2001 |title=Creationism Takes Root Where Europe, Asia Meet |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/292/5520/1286 |journal=Science |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |volume=292 |issue=5520 |pages=1286–1287 |doi=10.1126/science.292.5520.1286 |issn=0036-8075 |pmid=11360976 |accessdate=2014-06-20 |quote=Harassed but hard-headed, some gutsy Turkish scientists are stepping up their efforts to promote the teaching of the theory of evolution...}}</ref> US based creationist organizations such as the [[Institute for Creation Research]] (ICR) have worked alongside them.<!-- Koenig --> Some scientists have protested that anti-evolution books published by this group (such as ''The Evolution Deceit'' (1999) by Harun Yahya) have become more influential than real biology textbooks.<!-- Koenig --> The teaching of evolution in high schools has been fought by Ali Gören, a member of parliament and professor of medicine, who believes such education has negative effects.<!-- Koenig -->
The situation is very fragile, and the status of evolution in education varies from one government to the next. For example, in 1985 the [[Ministry of National Education (Turkey)|Minister of National Education, Youth and Sports]] [[:tr:Vehbi Dinçerler|Vehbi Dinçerler]] had scientific creationism added to high school texts, and also had the discredited [[Lamarckism]] presented alongside [[Darwinism]].<!-- Koenig --> Only in 1998 was this changed somewhat, with texts presenting a more balanced view, though still mentioning creationism and Lamarckism.<ref name=Koenig /> At present the moderate Islamist [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]], which is sympathetic to creationist views,<ref name="Edis" /> holds power. It was elected in 2002 and again with a greater majority in 2007.
In general, material that conflicts with religious beliefs is highly controversial in Turkey. For example, in November 2007 a prosecutor launched a probe into whether Richard Dawkins' book ''[[The God Delusion]]'' (2006) is "an attack on religious values." Its publisher could face trial and up to one year in prison if the prosecutor concludes that the book "incites religious hatred" and insults religious values.<ref name="AP_2007-11-28">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Turkey probes atheist's 'God' book |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/europe/11/28/dawkins.turkey.ap/index.html |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=November 28, 2007 |location=New York |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813055357/http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/europe/11/28/dawkins.turkey.ap/index.html |archivedate=2007-08-13 |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref>
Turkish academics who have defended evolutionary theory have received [[death threat]]s, for instance Turkish biologist Aykut Kence received an email telling him to enjoy his "final days."<ref name=Koenig /> Kence helped establish the Evolution Group, whose aim is to improve public understanding of evolution.<!-- Koenig --> However, opposition to creationism is not very powerful; Umit Sayin, a neurologist, describes academics and universities as "slow and sluggish" in their response.<!-- Koenig --> Kence maintains that "if knowledgeable people keep quiet, it only helps those who spread nonsense."<ref name=Koenig />
In June 2017, the education ministry announced the removal of evolution from the secondary school curriculum, scheduled to take effect in 2019; as of the date of the announcement the only other Muslim majority country where evolution is challenged in the education system was Saudi Arabia, where the concept is briefly named and heavily criticized in the curricula.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kingsley|first1=Patrick|title=Turkey Drops Evolution From Curriculum, Angering Secularists|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/23/world/europe/turkey-evolution-high-school-curriculum.html|work=The New York Times|date=23 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Frazier |first1=Kendrick |authorlink1=Kendrick Frazier |title=CFI, Richard Dawkins, Teachers Slam as 'Unconscionable' Turkey's Decision to Ban Teaching Evolution |journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |date=2017 |volume=41 |issue=5 |page=7}}</ref>
===United Kingdom===
In each of the countries of the [[United Kingdom]], there is an agreed syllabus for religious education with the right of parents to withdraw their children from these lessons. The religious education syllabus does not involve teaching creationism, but rather teaching the central tenets of major world faiths.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2002/13989.htm |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2002: United Kingdom |website=[[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor]] |publisher=[[United States Department of State]] |location=Washington, D.C. |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> At the same time, the teaching of evolution is compulsory in publicly funded schools. For instance, the [[National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)|National Curriculum]] for [[England]] requires that students at Key Stage 4 (14–16) be taught:<ref>{{cite hansard |title=Creationism |house=House of Commons |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/vo060227/text/60227131.htm |date=February 27, 2006 |column_start=518W |column_end=519W}}</ref> # that the fossil record is evidence for evolution # how variation and selection may lead to evolution or extinction
Similar requirements exist in [[Scotland]], [[Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland]].
In 2003, the [[Emmanuel Schools Foundation]] (previously the Vardy Foundation after its founder, [[Peter Vardy (businessman)|Sir Peter Vardy]]) sponsored a number of "faith-based" academies where evolution and creationist ideas would be taught side-by-side in science classes. This caused a considerable amount of controversy.<ref>{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Matthew |date=May 30, 2006 |title=Parents rebel at 'Dickensian' school run by millionaire evangelist friend of Blair |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/may/30/politics.schools |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref>
The former [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Rowan Williams]], has expressed his view that creationism should not be taught in schools.<ref>{{cite interview |last=William |first=Rowan |authorlink=Rowan Williams |interviewer=[[Alan Rusbridger]] |title=Interview: Rowan Williams |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/mar/21/religion.uk |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=March 21, 2006 | accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Fears over teaching creationism |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/4828238.stm |work=BBC News |location=London |publisher=BBC |date=March 21, 2006 |accessdate=2010-04-30}}</ref>
An organisation called [[Truth in Science]] has distributed teaching packs of creationist information to schools, and claims that fifty-nine schools are using the packs as "a useful classroom resource."<ref>{{cite news |last=Randerson |first=James |date=November 26, 2006 |title=Revealed: rise of creationism in UK schools |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2006/nov/27/controversiesinscience.religion |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |publisher=Guardian Media Group |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref> The government has stated that "Neither intelligent design nor creationism are recognised scientific theories and they are not included in the science curriculum. The Truth in Science information pack is therefore not an appropriate resource to support the science curriculum." It is arranging to communicate this message directly to schools.<ref>{{cite news |last=Randerson |first=James |date=December 6, 2006 |title=Ministers to ban creationist teaching aids in science lessons |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/dec/07/schools.religion |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |publisher=Guardian Media Group |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref>
The teaching of creationism and intelligent design in schools in the UK is being opposed by the [[British Centre for Science Education]] (BCSE).<ref name="EDOC11297" /><ref name="Nature">{{cite journal |last=Graebsch |first=Almut |author2=Schiermeier, Quirin |date=November 23, 2006 |title=Anti-evolutionists raise their profile in Europe |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=444 |pages=406–407 |doi=10.1038/444406a |pmid=17122815 |issue=7118}}</ref>
===United States=== {{Main|Creation and evolution in public education in the United States}} In the United States, creationists and proponents of evolution are engaged in a long-standing battle over the legal status of creation and evolution in the public school science classroom.<ref>{{cite news |last=Slevin |first=Peter |date=March 14, 2005 |title=Battle on Teaching Evolution Sharpens |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A32444-2005Mar13.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=The Washington Post Company |page=A01 |accessdate=2014-06-20}}</ref>

'''Dynamique des femmes jurists''' is a women's organisation in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. It was co-founded in 2006 by [[Nelly Mbangu]], director of the Democracy Research Center, who went on to become the first president of the organisation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nelly Mbangu|url=http://www.ffcrdc.org/team_member/7746/|publisher=Fonds pour les Femmes Congolaises|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref>
==Background== At the start of the 21st century the Democratic Republic of the Congo was suffering civil war with rebels fighting against government troops. In 2003 a peace accord was negotiated and in 2006 elections were held. However years of instability had resulted in much violence in the eastern part of the country which was described as the "rape capital of the world".<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/08/AR2007090801194.html |title=Prevalence of Rape in E. Congo Described as Worst in World |work=The Washington Post |date=9 September 2007 |accessdate=28 November 2017 |first=Stephanie |last=McCrummen}}</ref>
==Objectives== Dynamique des femmes jurists was set up to provide gender equality for women. The organisation aims to empower women so that they know what their rights are and are confident in obtaining them. These rights include the right to live unmolested, to have security of land tenure, to have access to basic social services, and to have access to the courts and tribunals. The organisation aims to encourage women to take up the law as a profession and then to represent other women who need their services, also to join trade unions, to participate in politics and to join in decision-making bodies in both the public and private sectors.<ref name=DFJ>{{cite web |url=http://www.dfj-rdc.org/ |title=Dynamique des femmes jurists |publisher=Dynamique des femmes jurists |accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> The organisation also offers psychological help to survivors of rape and [[female genital mutilation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=She is a humanitarian|url=https://www.careinternational.org.uk/sheisahumanitarian|publisher=Care International|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare | image = EscapeFirePoster.jpg | director = [[Matthew Heineman]]
[[Susan Frömke]] | producer = Matthew Heineman
Susan Frömke | executive producer = Doug Scott | photographer = Wolfgang Held | editor = Bradley Ross | music = Chad Kelly

Our Time Projects | released = {{Film date|2012|01|19|Sundance Film Festival|2012|10|05|United States}} | runtime = 99 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare''''' is a 2012 feature-length documentary directed by [[Matthew Heineman]] and [[Susan Froemke]] and released by [[Roadside Attractions]]. ''Escape Fire'' premiered at the [[Sundance Film Festival]],{{cite web|title=Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare (2012)|url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/escape-fire-the-fight-to-rescue-american-healthcare-v555062|publisher=All Rovi|accessdate=21 December 2012}} opened in select theaters on October 5, 2012, and was simultaneously released on iTunes and Video-on-Demand. The film was released on DVD in February 2013 and premiered on CNN on March 10, 2013. ==Reception== Since ''Escape Fire'' premiered at Sundance, the film has been mentioned or reviewed in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[Forbes]]'',{{cite news|last=Chase|first=Dave|title=Escape Fire Documentary: Solutions to Healthcare's Conflagration|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davechase/2012/10/05/escape-fire-artists-will-transform-healthcare/|accessdate=5 October 2012|work=Forbes|date=5 October 2012}} ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine,{{cite web|title=Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare|url=http://nymag.com/listings/movie/escape-fire-the-fight-to/}} ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',{{cite news|last=Turan|first=Kenneth|title=Review: 'Escape Fire' calls for drastic changes to U.S. healthcare|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-escape-fire-20121005,0,1968361.story|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=5 October 2012|date=4 October 2012}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' and other media outlets. The film received generally positive reviews, with an aggregate score of 67 on Metacritic http://www.metacritic.com/movie/escape-fire-the-fight-to-rescue-american-healthcare and 81% on Rotten Tomatoes.http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/escape_fire_the_fight_to_rescue_american_healthcare/ It was a ''[[New York Times]]'',{{cite news|last=CATSOULIS|first=JEANNETTE|title=Pitting Drug Regimens Against Prevention|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2012/10/05/movies/escape-fire-the-fight-to-rescue-american-healthcare.html?ref=movies&_r=2&|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=5 October 2012|date=4 October 2012}} ''New York'' magazine, and ''[[Washington Post]]'' Critics’ Pick. ==Festivals== * Sundance Film Festival, 2012: Grand Jury Prize (Nominated); [[Candescent Films|Candescent Award]] Given to One Outstanding Socially Conscious Documentary (Winner) * Full Frame Film Festival, 2012: Human Rights Award (Winner) * Silverdocs Film Festival, 2012: Social Issue Award (Winner) * Newport Beach Film Festival, 2012: Outstanding Achievement in Directing (Winner); Outstanding Achievement in Documentary Filmmaking (Winner) * Heartland Film Festival, 2012: Truly Moving Picture’s Crystal Heart Award (Winner) ==Origin of title== In the research phase of ''Escape Fire'', the filmmakers came across an influential speech delivered by Dr. [[Donald Berwick]] years before he took office as the head of Medicare and Medicaid. The speech was published as a healthcare manifesto called “Escape Fire: Lessons for the Future of Healthcare.” Dr. Berwick draws a parallel between American healthcare and a 1949 [[Mann Gulch fire]] in Montana. Just as the healthcare system lies perilously on the brink of combustion, the forest fire that seemed harmless at first was waiting to explode. A team of fifteen smoke-jumpers parachuted in to contain the fire, but soon they were running for their lives, racing to the top of a steep ridge. Their foreman, Wag Dodge, recognized that they would not make it. With the fire barely two hundred yards behind him, he invented an on-the-spot solution. He took some matches out of his pocket, bent down and set fire to the grass directly in front of him. The fire spread quickly uphill, and he stepped into the middle of the newly burnt area, calling for his crew to join him. The crew did not, and the fire raged past Wag Dodge and overtook the crew, killing thirteen men and burning 3,200 acres. Dodge survived, nearly unharmed. Dodge had invented what is now called an “[[escape fire]],” and soon after it became standard practice. As Berwick says in the film, “We’re in Mann Gulch. Healthcare, it’s in really bad trouble. The answer is among us. Can we please stop and think and make sense of the situation and get our way out of it?” ==Outreach and impact== Since the film’s Sundance premiere in January 2012, ''Escape Fire'' has been at the center of an outreach campaign to engage general, educational, professional and institutional audiences interested in changing health and healthcare at the individual, community and national level. The ''Escape Fire'' website,{{cite web|title=Escape Fire Official Site|url=http://escapefiremovie.com}} provides consumer and educational tools for the outreach and engagement campaign. It includes a virtual First Aid Kit,{{cite web|title=Escape Fire First Aid Kit|url=http://www.escapefiremovie.com/first-aid-kit|publisher=Our Time Projects}} with innovative tools for individuals to change themselves and their communities. A 28-page discussion guide{{cite web|title=Escape Fire Discussion Guide|url=http://www.escapefiremovie.com/pdf/discussionguide.pdf|publisher=Our Time Projects}} is provided on the site for screening organizers, facilitators and educators. Background information is available on the key healthcare issues addressed in the film, including problems of over-medication; paying more and getting less; reimbursement for services not quality of care, and the need for more systemic support of disease prevention. After viewing a military screening of the film, Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) was inspired to address the issue, and successfully ushered through a bi-partisan amendment to the [[National Defense Authorization Act]], which passed the Senate in late 2012. This amendment would allow the VA to take back controlled substances - such as pharmaceutical drugs - from soldiers to prevent overmedication and suicide. The amendment did not win final passage in the 112th Congress, which ended on January 3, 2013, but is expected to be re-introduced in the Spring of 2013. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.escapefiremovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|tt2093109|Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare}} {{CNN Films}} [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Documentary films about health care]] [[Category:Healthcare reform in the United States‎]] [[Category:Roadside Attractions films]]

{{Infobox Korean name|title=|hangul=교린 정책|hanja=交隣政策|rr=kyorin chŏngch'aek|mr=gyorin jeongchaek}} '''Gyorin''' (lit. "neighborly relations") was a [[neo-Confucian]] term developed in [[Joseon Dynasty|Joseon]] [[Korea]]. The term was intended to identify and characterize a diplomatic policy which establishes and maintains amicable relations with neighboring states. It was construed and understood in tandem with a corollary term, which was the ''[[Sadaejuui|sadae]]'' or "serving the great" policy towards [[History of China#Imperial era|Imperial China]].<ref>Yim Min-Hyeok. [http://www.dbpia.co.kr/view/ar_view.asp?arid=1160482 "The Establishment of Literati Governance Society in Early Joseon, and Its Continuation,"] ''The Review of Korean Studies,'' Vol. 8, No. 2 (June 20050, pp. 223-254.</ref>
Confucian learning contributed in the formation of ''gyorin'' and ''sadae'' as ritual, conceptual and normative frameworks for construing interactions and political decision-making.<ref>Steben, Barry D. [http://www.chinajapan.org/articles/11.1/11.1steben39-60.pdf. "The Transmission of Neo-Confucianism to the Ryukyu (Liuqiu) Islands and Its Historical Significance: Ritual and Rectification of Names in a Bipolar Authority Field," p. 54.]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[National University of Singapore]].</ref>
==Multi-national foreign policy== The rationale expressed by ''gyorin'' was applied to a multi-national foreign policy.<ref>{{ko icon}} [http://enc.daum.net/dic100/contents.do?query1=b10s4187a 사대교린 (조선 외교), Britannica online Korea]</ref> Scholarly writing about the Joseon dynasty has tended to focus on diplomatic relations with China and [[Japan]], but the intermediary nature of ''gyorin'' contacts—for example, Joseon-Ryukyuan diplomatic and trading contacts—were important as well.<ref>Kim, Chun-gil. [https://books.google.com/books?id=WBZjBPt1H8AC&pg=PA76&dq= ''The History of Korea,'' pp. 76-77;] Oh Youngkyo. [http://khistory.korea.ac.kr/bbs/table/koreanhistory/upload/0305_003.pdf "State of Research on the Late Period of the Choson Dynasty,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722132650/http://khistory.korea.ac.kr/bbs/table/koreanhistory/upload/0305_003.pdf |date=2011-07-22 }} [[Yonsei University]].</ref> Envoys from the [[Ryūkyū Kingdom]] were received by [[Taejo of Joseon]] in 1392, 1394 and 1397. [[Siam]] sent an envoy to Taejo's court in 1393.<ref name="goodrich1601">Goodrich, L. Carrington ''et al.'' (1976). [https://books.google.com/books?id=JWpF-dObxW8C&lpg=PA1193&vq=ryukyu&dq=luther%20carrington%20goodrich&pg=PA1601#v=snippet&q=liu-ch'iu&f=false ''Dictionary of Ming biography, 1368-1644'' (明代名人傳), Vol. II, p. 1601.]</ref>
The long-term, strategic ''gyorin'' policy played out in [[Bilateralism|bilateral]] diplomacy and trade dealings with [[Jurchen people|Jurchen]], Japan, Ryūkyū Kingdom, Siam and others.<ref>Kim, [https://books.google.com/books?id=WBZjBPt1H8AC&pg=PA76&dq= pp. 76-77;] [http://www.raskb.com/ Royal Asiatic Society, Korea Branch] (RASKB): [http://www.raskb.com/zboard/view.php?id=raslecture&page=1&sn1=&divpage=1&sn=off&ss=on&sc=on&select_arrange=headnum&desc=asc&no=127 [[Yi Sugwang]] with Vietnamese counterpart [[Phùng Khắc Khoan]] in 1597.]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Over time, diplomatic and trade policies were perceived by Joseon's partners as the traditional door through which trends in neo-Confucian philosophical principles were recognized.<ref>Steben, p. 57.</ref>
The Joseon kingdom made every effort to maintain a friendly bilateral relationship with China for reasons having to do with both ''[[realpolitik]]'' and a more idealist Confucian worldview wherein China was seen as the center of a Confucian moral universe.<ref>Mansourov, Alexandre Y. [http://www.asiaquarterly.com/content/view/174/43/ "Will Flowers Bloom without Fragrance? Korean-Chinese Relations,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108074830/http://www.asiaquarterly.com/content/view/174/43/ |date=2008-01-08 }} ''Harvard Asia Quarterly'' (Spring 2009).</ref> Joseon diplomacy was no less aware and sensitive to ''realpolitik'' in the implementation of ''gyorin'' policy.
The unique nature of ''gyorin'' bilateral diplomatic exchanges evolved from a conceptual framework developed by the Chinese. Gradually, the theoretical models would be modified, mirroring the evolution of a unique relationship.<ref>Toby, Ronald P. (1991). [https://books.google.com/books?id=2hK7tczn2QoC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=korean+diplomacy+1711&source=bl&ots=k4W8TZxzjN&sig=Zi2nOmpTuZUK9bQL9ulL_Jnt47k&hl=en&ei=YJmtSeGQIeH8tgfknIWLBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA87,M1 ''State and Diplomacy in Early Modern Japan: Asia in the Development of the Tokugawa Bakufu,'' p. 87.]</ref>
==See also== * [[Joseon diplomacy]] * [[Neo-Confucianism]]

[https://books.google.com/books?id=067On0JgItAC&dq=luther+carrington+goodrich&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Dictionary of Ming biography, 1368-1644'' (明代名人傳), Vol. I;] [https://books.google.com/books?id=JWpF-dObxW8C&dq=luther+carrington+goodrich&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Dictionary of Ming biography, 1368-1644'' (明代名人傳), Vol. II.] New York: [[Columbia University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-231-03801-0}}; {{ISBN|978-0-231-03833-1}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1622199 OCLC 1622199] * Kang, Etsuko Hae-jin. (1997). ''Diplomacy and Ideology in Japanese-Korean Relations: from the Fifteenth to the Eighteenth Century.'' Basingstoke, Hampshire; Macmillan. {{ISBN|978-0-312-17370-8}}; {{OCLC|243874305}} * Kang, Jae-eun and Suzanne Lee. (2006). ''The Land of Scholars : Two Thousand Years of Korean Confucianism.'' Paramus, New Jersey: Homa & Sekey Books. {{ISBN|978-1-931907-37-8}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/60931394?referer=di&ht=edition OCLC 60931394] * Kim, Chun-gil. (2005). ''The history of Korea.'' Westport, Connecticut: [[Greenwood Publishing Group]]. {{ISBN|978-0-313-33296-8}}; {{ISBN|978-0-313-03853-2}}; {{OCLC|217866287}} * Mansourov, Alexandre Y. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080108074830/http://www.asiaquarterly.com/content/view/174/43/ "Will Flowers Bloom without Fragrance? Korean-Chinese Relations,"] ''Harvard Asia Quarterly'' (Spring 2009). * Oh Youngkyo. [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722132650/http://khistory.korea.ac.kr/bbs/table/koreanhistory/upload/0305_003.pdf "State of Research on the Late Period of the Choson Dynasty,"] [[Yonsei University]]. * Steben, Barry D. [http://www.chinajapan.org/articles/11.1/11.1steben39-60.pdf. "The Transmission of Neo-Confucianism to the Ryukyu (Liuqiu) Islands and Its Historical Significance: Ritual and Rectification of Names in a Bipolar Authority Field,"]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[National University of Singapore]]. * Toby, Ronald P. (1991). [https://books.google.com/books?id=2hK7tczn2QoC&pg=PP1&dq=State+and+Diplomacy+in+Early+Modern+Japan&client=firefox-a&sig=ACfU3U2LUEdVPEFLwBwAI5-9f4HrhECGFg ''State and Diplomacy in Early Modern Japan: Asia in the Development of the Tokugawa Bakufu.''] Stanford: [[Stanford University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-1951-3}}
